questions.text: A patient is having pain over the deltoid muscle just below the acromion process. On examination, pain is absent at the same point when the patient abducts the arm. What could be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• In subacromial bursitis, pressure over the deltoid, below the acromion process with the arm by the side causes pain.
  • However, when the arm is abducted, pressure over the same point causes no pain, because the bursa disappears under the acromion process (Dawbarn's sign).
  • Subacromial or subdeltoid bursitis is usually secondary to inflammation of the supraspinatus tendon.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia: Human Anatomy, Volume-1, 8th Edition, Page Number-78.

questions.text: All the following pelvic structures support the vagina except?
questions.solution:
Supports of vagina

De Lancey introduced three level system of support -

  • Level I - Uterosacral and cardinal ligaments support the uterus and vaginal vault. The cervix remains at or just above the ischial spines, and the vagina lies horizontally.
  • Level II - Pelvic fascias and para colpos which connects the vagina to the white line on the lateral pelvic wall through the arcus This includes the pubo cervical fascia anteriorly and the rectovaginal fascia and septum posteriorly.
  • Level III -Levator ani muscle supports the lower one third of the vagina. The levator muscle forms a platform against which the pelvic organs (uterus and upper vagina) gets compressed during straining.
  • Perineal body includes levator ani muscles, bulbospongisus, superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles, external anal and urethral spincters, all of which are included in supports of uterus. Hence, answer here is option D which is not included in support of uterus.

questions.text: Methylation of the cytidine residues of DNA will cause:
questions.solution:
• DNA methylation, involving the addition of a methyl group to cytosine residues, which generally leads to a decrease in gene expression. Methylation modifies chromatin structure, making it less accessible to transcriptional machinery, and is often associated with gene silencing.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 30th Edition, Page Number-438.

questions.text: A PHC is designated as Type A if it conducts less than - specified number of deliveries.
questions.solution:
Primary Health Centres (PHCs) are an integral part of the healthcare infrastructure, especially in rural areas, providing essential primary healthcare services to the population. The categorization of PHCs into Type A, B, or C depends on various factors, including the number of deliveries conducted.

Why the other options are not correct:

A. 10: This number is too low to be considered a threshold for categorizing a PHC as Type A. PHCs typically handle a higher volume of deliveries to serve the needs of the population adequately.

B. 15: Similar to option A, 15 deliveries are also insufficient to categorize a PHC as Type A. PHCs are expected to handle a larger caseload to qualify for this classification.

D. 30: While 30 deliveries might be a significant number for a smaller healthcare facility, it is not typically the threshold for categorizing a PHC as Type A. PHCs often handle more deliveries than this before being classified into a higher type.

Therefore, option C, 20 deliveries, is the most appropriate threshold for determining the classification of a PHC as Type A. If a PHC conducts fewer than 20 deliveries, it is considered Type A, indicating that it may have limited facilities for childbirth and may need to refer complicated cases to higher-level healthcare facilities

choices.text: Physostigmine is contraindicated in all cases
Sodium bicarbonate should be administered to treat acidosis
Atropine sulphate should be administered as an antidote
Diazepam should be injected to control seizures

questions.text: A 45 year old female patient having depression with suicidal tendency took a massive dose of amitriptyline in an attempt to commit suicide and was immediately brought to emergency department. Which of the following statements regarding the management is least useful?
questions.solution:
Tricyclic antidepressants like amitriptyline are competitive antagonists of muscarinic receptors. Atropine being an antimuscarinic drug should not be administered.

Acute Poisoning with TCAs is frequent; usually self-attempted for suicide

Manifestations are:

Excitement, delirium and other anticholinergic symptoms as seen in atropine poisoning, followed by muscle spasms, convulsions and coma.

Respiration is depressed, body temperature may fall, BP is low, tachycardia is prominent.

ECG changes and ventricular arrhythmias are common.

Treatment is primarily supportive with gastric lavage, respiratory assistance, fluid infusion, maintenance of BP and body temperature.

Acidosis must be corrected by bicarbonate infusion.

Diazepam may be injected i.v. to control convulsions and delirium.

Most important is the treatment of cardiac arrhythmias, for which propranolol/ lidocaine may be used.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, Page no. 487

questions.text: Which is the most common bladder carcinoma caused by schistosoma haematobium?
questions.solution:
Schistosoma haematobium infections are a risk factor for bladder carcinoma. The most common type is squamous cell carcinoma, with 70% of cases being squamous, and the remainder being urothelial or glandular.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page Number-958.

questions.text: The pulse character tracing shown below is most likely that of a patient with :
questions.solution: Pulsus alternans (alternation of one strong and one weak beat without a change in the cycle length) occurs most commonly in left ventricular failure.

choices.text: Ventral rami of C1, C2 spinal root
Ventral rami of C2, C3 spinal root
Ventral rami of C3, C4 spinal root
Ventral rami of C4, C5 spinal root

questions.text: Proprioceptive branches to sternocleidomastoid muscle are derived from:
questions.solution:
Nerve supply of sternocleidomastoid muscle:

  1. The spinal accessory nerve provides the motor supply. It passes through the muscle.
  2. Branches from the ventral rami of C2 and C3 are proprioceptive.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia: Human Anatomy, Volume-3, 8th Edition, Page Number-91.

questions.text: A woman comes to your OPD with a history of domestic violence. She alleged that she was hit with a frying pan on her head 2 days back. What would you expect the colour of the bruise to be?
questions.solution:
Subconjunctival ecchymosis does not undergo the usual colour changes due to diffusion of atmospheric oxygen through the conjunctival tissue. They are at first bright red, then yellow before disappearing.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology by KS Narayan Reddy, 35th Edition, Page Number-137.

questions.text: A child presented with abdominal discomfort and intermittent abdominal pain. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the given radiograph ?
questions.solution:
From the given radiograph the arrow pointing towards bowel loops herniated there in right hemithorax on medial part

  • Right anteromedial aspect - Morgagni hernia
  • Left posterolateral aspect - Bochdalek hernia

questions.text: The image shows the endoscopic picture of a 73 year old male admitted for evaluation of GI bleeding. What is the most likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution: Gastric antral vascular ectasia (GAVE) syndrome, also known as watermelon stomach is a significant cause of acute or chronic gastrointestinal blood loss in the elderly is characterized endoscopically by 'watermelon stripes.'

choices.text: Criminal court gets priority over civil court, if both are of the same level
Conduct money may be offered to witnesses in criminal cases
The amount to be paid in conduct money is decided by the judge

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding summons?
questions.solution:
Summons or subpoena is a document compelling the attendance of a witness in a Court of law under penalty, on a particular day, time and place, for the purpose of giving evidence.

Section 61 to Section 69 of Cr.P.C. deal with summons.

Conduct money is offered only in civil cases and not in criminal cases. The amount of conduct money to be paid is decided by the judge.

If a witness receives two summons to attend two different courts on the same day, higher courts have priority over lower courts and criminal cases get priority over civil cases. If both courts are of the same level, either civil or criminal, he has to attend the court from which he received the summons first and inform the other court, (Option B).

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology by KS Narayan Reddy, 35th Edition, Page Number-7.

questions.text: A 25-year-old HIV positive female taking ART complaints of pulsatile headache. She is prescribed ergotamine. She now develops tingling and pain in toe radiating upwards till mid thigh. Dorsalis pedis and popliteal artery pulsations are not felt bilaterally. CT angio is shown. What is the likely etiology?
questions.solution: Ergotamine derivatives are substrates of CYP3A4 metabolism and as such are contraindicated for concomitant use with medications established as strong CYP3A4 inhibitors (protease inhibitors, some macrolide antibiotics, azole antifungals) because of the production of acute ergot toxicity. ergotamine derivatives are substrates of CYP3A4 metabolism and as such are contraindicated for concomitant use with medications established as strong CYP3A4 inhibitors (protease inhibitors, some macrolide antibiotics, azole antifungals) because of the production of acute ergot toxicity.

questions.text: Patient developed a head injury with midline shift, NCCT is shown below. What will you do next as the appropriate management?
questions.solution:
In head injury patients, the prime aim to prevent Secondary brain damage is to reduce Intra cranial pressure:

  • IV mannitol is the Drug of Choice
  • If BP is normal - Frusemide can be used
  • Sedation with Barbiturates is used ( Don't use Diazepam as they suppress the respiration)
  • Steroids must not be used in high ICP due to trauma, we can use only in Tumors.

Only after decreasing ICP, we will plan for Burr hole evacuation, which is the Treatment of choice for this case.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions a hand sanitizer cannot be used?
questions.solution:
Hand Hygiene

  • Hands are the main source of transmission of infections during healthcare. Hand hygiene is therefore the most important measure to avoid the transmission of harmful microbes and prevent healthcare-associated infections.
  • Types of Hand Hygiene Methods
    • Hand Rub
      • Alcohol based (70-80% ethyl alcohol) and chlorhexidine (2-4%) based hand rubs are available.
      • The duration of contact has to be at least for 20-30 seconds.
      • Advantage: After a period of contact, it gets evaporated on its own hence drying of hands is not required separately.
      • Indications:
        1. Hand rub is indicated during routine rounds in the wards or ICUs;
        2. In all the moments or situations requiring hand hygiene, except when the hands are visibly dirty or soiled, when it will be ineffective.
    • Hand Wash
      • Antimicrobial soaps (liquid, gel or bars) are available.
      • If facilities are not available, then even ordinary soap and water can also be used.
      • The duration of contact has to be at least for 40-60 seconds.
      • Hand washing is indicated in the following situations:
        1. When the hands are visibly soiled with blood, excreta, pus, etc.
        2. Before and after eating
        3. After going to toilet
        4. Before and after shift of the duty

Five Moments for Hand Hygiene

The World Health Organization (WHO) has published standard guidelines describing the situations or opportunities when hand hygiene is indicated in healthcare sectors:


Steps of Hand Rubbing and Hand Washing

WHO has also laid down the guidelines describing the appropriate steps involved for an effective hand rubbing and hand washing:


Hand rub is not preferred when hands are visibly soiled. In the case of hand soiling, hand wash is preferred.

Reference: WHO Guidelines on Hand Hygiene in Health Care.

choices.text: It is also called pincushion distortion
It is due to wearing of cylindrical glasses
It can be due to asymmetrical convex lenses in both the eyes
It is due to high power convex lenses

questions.text: A 35 year old male complains of vision distortion. Distortion increases progressively in both the meridians on wearing his spectacles. All the following are correct regarding the patient's problem except-
questions.solution:
PIN CUSHION DISTORTION


Barrel and pin cushion distortion



  • In pincushion distortion, image magnification increases with the distance from the optical axis. The visible effect is that lines that do not go through the centre of the image are bowed inwards, towards the centre of the image, like a pincushion.
  • Convex (plus) spherical lenses tend to have pincushion distortion.
  • In barrel distortion, image magnification decreases with distance from the optical axis. The apparent effect is that of an image which has been mapped around a sphere (or barrel).
  • On wearing cylindrical lenses, i.e. correction of astigmatism, the distortion should decrease in both the axis, not increase.

questions.text: Most common site of intracerebral haemorrhage is:
questions.solution:
• Most common site of intracerebral haemorrhage is putamen (basal ganglia).
  • Most commonly seen in elderly hypertensive individuals.
  • It is due to the rupture of Charcot's artery (Lenticulo-striae branch of Middle cerebral artery).

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology by KS Narayan Reddy, 35th Edition, Page Number-201.

questions.text: Glucose transported via facilitated transport that is insulin-sensitive (dependent) takes place in all except:
questions.solution:
• Insulin plays a crucial role in glucose transport by promoting the translocation of glucose transporters (GLUT) to the cell membrane. In insulin-sensitive tissues, such as skeletal muscle, adipose tissue, and the heart, GLUT4 is involved in facilitated glucose transport. However, the liver primarily uses GLUT2, which is not insulin-dependent. In the liver, glucose transport is not significantly influenced by insulin, as the liver needs to regulate glucose levels through both glucose uptake and release.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 30th Edition, Page Number-191.

questions.text: Probiotics are useful for:
questions.solution:
Probiotics are beneficial in various conditions, and they are particularly useful in preventing and treating necrotizing enterocolitis, a condition that affects the intestines of premature infants.

The pathophysiology of NEC is inflammation of the intestine leading to bacterial invasion causing cellular damage and cellular death, and necrosis of the colon and intestine.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Page Number-649.

questions.text: Which of the following hormone does not cause hyperglycemia and can be used in diabetes mellitus management?
questions.solution:
Islet amyloid peptide (amylin) is produced from pancreatic beta cell. It acts in specific regions of hindbrain resulting in reduction in glucagon release, delayed gastric emptying and satiety.

A synthetic analog pramlintide Is used in the management of diabetes.

Pramlintide It is a synthetic amylin analogue which on s.c. injection before meal attenuates postprandial glycaemia and exerts a centrally mediated anorectic action.

It is used to supplement meal time insulin injection when insulin alone fails to control post prandial glycaemic peak, in both type 1 and type 2 diabetics.

Hypoglycaemia is the most important adverse effect.

Loss of appetite, nausea and vomiting are the other side effects. Reduction in body weight is an additional benefit.

Glucocorticoids, glucagon and growth hormone oppose insulin action on glucose levels and causes hyperglycemia.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, Page no. 293

questions.text: A neonate was born at term, and did not cry after birth. Resuscitation was started and the baby was connected to the ECG and SPO2 monitor at 3 minutes of life. Which limb is usually preferred for accurate pre-ductal SpO2 measurement in such a neonate?
questions.solution:
An oximeter should be used to confirm the perception of cyanosis when PPV is required for more than a few breaths, whenever resuscitation is anticipated, and when supplemental oxygen is administered.

  • Conventionally, the pulse oximeter is always placed in the right hand owing to pre-ductal saturation being more accurate.
  • Remember that the right hand receives blood supply from the right subclavian artery, which is a pre-ductal structure.

Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st Edition, Chapter 121; NRP Guidelines, 8th Edition.

choices.text: Maximum breast tissue is in inner quadrant
Tail of spence touches anterior axillary fold
Cooper ligament only in upper part of breast

questions.text: True regarding breast anatomy
questions.solution:
• Maximum Breast tissue is seen in Upper Outer Quadrant ( that's why cancer is more common in this quadrant)
  • 10-100 Lobules are present, which drains into 5-9 major lactiferous ducts.
  • Axillary tail of spence extends upto anterior axillary fold and in some patients, well developed axillary tail is mistaken for a lipoma, Lymph node or a separate mass.
  • Ligament of cooper is seen attaching from pectoralis fascia to dermis and seen all over the breast.
  • Areola and nipple contain involuntary muscles- Circular ERECTION muscle called as SAPPEY'S MUSCLE; Longitudinal RETRACTION MUSCLE Called as MYERHOLTZ MUSCLE.
  • Numerous Sebaceous glands around the Areola enlarge at pregnancy and called as MONTOGOMERY TUBERCLES.

Reference: Bailey 28th Edition page 915

questions.text: A 67-year-old patient named Arjun was administered a local anaesthetic agent. He developed tachycardia, hypotension, arrhythmias, and cardiovascular collapse. Which of the following should be used for treatment of this patient?
questions.solution:
Administer 1.5 mL/kg as an initial bolus; the bolus can be repeated 1- 2 times for persistent asystole. Start an infusion at 0.25 mL/kg/min for 30-60 minutes and then increase the infusion rate up to 0.50 mL/kg/min for refractory hypotension.

Bupivacaine is a local anaesthetic known for its cardiotoxic effects. In cases of toxic doses leading to cardiovascular collapse, intravenous lipid emulsion, such as 20 % intralipid, has been found to be extremely useful. It helps in the management of refractory arrhythmias associated with local anaesthetic toxicity. Other interventions, such as diazepam for convulsions and avoidance of lignocaine as an antiarrhythmic, are also mentioned.

Reference: Ajay Yadav's Short Textbook of Anaesthesia, 2nd Edition, Page Number-110.

questions.text: An extreme degree of sadism in which the person after mutilating the body, sucks or licks the wounds, bites the skin, drinks blood and eats the flesh of his victim to derive sexual pleasure is called as:
questions.solution:
OPTION A : Necrophilia - Desire of having sex with the dead body

OPTION B : Klismaphilia - Using Enema

OPTION C : Fetishism - Using inanimate objects for sexual gratification

OPTION D : Necrophagia - Eating dead tissue and dead body

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presents with a 3-month history of increasing difficulty in getting out of a chair and brushing her hair. She also reports difficulty in swallowing solids. Physical examination reveals dilated blood vessels seen under the nails and multiple violaceous papules over the interphalangeal and metacarpophalangeal joints. Sensation, deep tendon reflexes are intact. Which of the following is the next appropriate test?
questions.solution:
• The presence of cutaneous findings (periungual telangiectasias, gottrons papules) in addition to proximal symmetric muscle weakness suggests a diagnosis of dermatomyositis in this patient.
  • Pathognomonic findings of dermatomyositis include the following:
  • Gottron papules:dorsal metacarpophalangeal and interphalangeal joints may show the presence of overlying erythematous or violaceous papules with or without scaling or ulceration.
  • Heliotrope rash:This is a characteristic skin finding of dermatomyositis and presents with a violaceous, or an erythematous rash affecting the upper eyelids with or without periorbital edema. This finding may not be apparent in patients with dark skin patients.
  • Dermatomyositis, polymyositis, inclusion body myositis, and necrotizing autoimmune myopathy are the most common idiopathic inflammatory myopathies. They are characterized by elevation of muscle enzymes such as creatine kinase.
  • Initial testing in suspected cases of dermatomyositis should include muscle enzymes, such as creatine kinase (CK), aldolase, lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), aspartate aminotransferase (AST) and alanine aminotransferase (ALT). Testing for muscle enzymes helps to guide further diagnostic studies and to assess response to therapy
  • Other studies that can aid in the diagnosis - electromyography and muscle biopsy. Muscle biopsy in patients with dermatomyositis initially shows perifascicular atrophy but can progress to necrosis of the muscle fibers in later stages of dermatomyositis.
  • Antinuclear antibodies (ANA) are present in a majority of patients with dermatomyositis but do not help to make a diagnosis
  • Anti-Jo is the most common antisynthetase antibody found in dermatomyositis.

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology, 9th edition chapter 53

questions.text: Which of the following is a non-immunologic cause of thrombocytopenia?
questions.solution:
The most important non-immunologic causes of thrombocytopenia include disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) and thrombotic microangiopathies. In these conditions, unbridled, often systemic, platelet activation reduces the platelet lifespan.

Additionally, mechanical injury, such as that from prosthetic heart valves, can lead to non-immunologic destruction of the platelets.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page Number-664.

questions.text: Earliest event among the following in Diabetic Nephropathy?
questions.solution: Initially there is an increase in GFR due to glomerular hyperperfusion and renal hypertrophy, later GFR is brought back to normal by thickening of glomerular basement membrane, glomerular hypertrophy and mesangial volume expansion.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient had a fracture of the upper end of the fibula. After a few weeks, he develops loss of sensation over the lower lateral part of the leg and dorsum of the foot. Which of the following nerves is involved in this case?
questions.solution:
The superficial peroneal nerve:

  • It is a branch of the common peroneal nerve.
  • It arises on the lateral side of the neck of the fibula deep to the fibers of the peroneus longus.
  • It descends between the peroneal muscles, pierces the deep fascia at the junction of the upper two-thirds and lower one-third of the lateral side of the leg, and divides into medial and lateral branches.
  • These branches supply the following area:
    • The skin over the lower one-third of the lateral side of the leg.
    • The skin over the entire dorsum of the foot with the exception of the following areas.
      • Lateral border, supplied by sural nerve.
      • Medial border up to the base of the great toe, supplied by the saphenous nerve.
      • Cleft between the first and second toes, supplied by the deep peroneal nerve.
      • Distal phalanges including nail beds of 1-5 toes.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia: Human Anatomy, Volume-2, 8th Edition, Page Number 107-108.

choices.text: There is no place for a wait-and-watch policy
Dehydration and ketoacidosis should be promptly corrected
Oxytocin has got a definite place in the management
Uterus should be explored as a routine following delivery

questions.text: The following statements are related to the management of obstructed labour except:
questions.solution:
Oxytocin should not be used in the management of obstructed labor.

The primary principles for the management of obstructed labor involve Prompt intervention, Correction of dehydration and ketoacidosis, and Exploration of the uterus if necessary.

Oxytocin is not recommended in cases of obstructed labor.

choices.text: Nasal wash for influenza and RSV

questions.text: A 2.5-year-old child presents with high grade fever, barking cough and stridor while crying. The child accepts fluids normally. On examination, the respiratory rate is 34/min and temperature is 102F. What is the next best step in the management of this child?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis in this case is mild croup, because the child has fever, stridor and barking cough. As per the table given in OP Ghai 10th edition, stridor only on cough or crying is mild croup while stridor at rest indicates moderate to severe croup.

  • Effectiveness of oral corticosteroids: Oral corticosteroids are effective in viral croup as they reduce laryngeal mucosa edema through their anti-inflammatory action. They are beneficial even in mild croup, reducing hospitalization, duration of hospitalization, and the need for additional interventions like epinephrine.
  • Indications for nebulized epinephrine: Nebulized epinephrine is indicated for moderate to severe croup, including in cases with moderate to severe stridor at rest, possible need for intubation, respiratory distress, and hypoxia. It is not typically used for mild croup.
  • Antibiotics are not indicated: Antibiotics are not typically indicated in croup as it is primarily caused by viral infections.

Reference: OP Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition, Table 15.3; Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 20th Edition, Page Number-2034.

questions.text: There are 20 amino acids with three codons even though the number of amino acids that could be formed is 64, leading to an amino acid being represented by more than one codon. This is called:
questions.solution:
• The concept that multiple codons can code for the same amino acid is called degeneracy. This redundancy in the genetic code allows for variations in the DNA sequence without altering the amino acid sequence during protein synthesis.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 30th Edition, Page Number-415.

questions.text: A 46-year-old female suffering from severe menorrhagia underwent hysterectomy. She wishes to take hormone replacement therapy. Physical examination and breast are normal, but X-ray shows osteoporosis. The treatment of choice is:
questions.solution:
• The female underwent hysterectomy, i.e. surgical menopause at the age of 48 years and her X-ray shows osteoporosis - hence HRT can be advised.
  • Both estrogen alone or estrogen + progesterone can be used for treating osteoporosis. The choice depends on whether uterus is present or not (i.e. patient is hysterectomized or not).

We have already discussed the agents used for treating osteoporosis and as I have mentioned earlier, bisphosphonates are the first line of treatment for osteoporosis.

"For women with a uterus, a progestin should be combined with an estrogen, to lower the risk of endometrial cancer". - William Gynae, 1st edition, page 495.

All women who have intact uterus or even those who underwent hysterectomy for endometrial cancer (Stage I), endometroid ovarian tumors or endometriosis or those with severe osteoporosis should receive combined estrogen - progesterone therapy or be considered for selective estrogen receptor modulator therapy (SERM therapy).

Reference: Williams Gynaecology, 1st Edition, Page Number 495, 499-500.

choices.text: Red fibers have less blood supply and mitochondria than white fibers
Red fibers are also innervated by smaller nerve fibers.
Red fibers contain large amounts of myoglobin than White fibers

questions.text: Following are characteristic of Red muscle fibers except
questions.solution:
Characteristics of Red muscle fibres

  • The myoglobin gives the slow muscle a reddish appearance
  • Slow fibers are smaller than fast fibers & innervated by smaller nerve fibers.
  • Red fibres have a more extensive blood vessel system and more capillaries to supply extra amounts of oxygen compared with fast fibers.
  • Fibers have greatly increased numbers of mitochondria to support high levels of oxidative metabolism.
  • Slow fibers contain large amounts of myoglobin, an iron-containing protein similar to hemoglobin in red blood cells. Myoglobin combines with oxygen and stores it until needed, which also greatly speeds oxygen transport to the mitochondria.

Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology 14th Ed Pg 88

questions.text: A 34 year old female brought to medicine department seeking treatment for long standing history of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS). She was later prescribed an agent by her physician. After some days of taking the medicine she was brought to emergency room with acute abdominal pain, occult blood in stool with nausea & diarrhoea. She was later diagnosed of having Ischemic colitis. Which amongst the following agent is responsible for the same?
questions.solution:
Alosetron is a potent antagonist of the 5HT3 receptor.

The 5HT3 receptor participates in sensitization of spinal sensory neurons, vagal signaling of nausea, and peristaltic reflexes. The clinical effect of 5HT3 antagonism is a general reduction in GI contractility with decreased colonic transit, along with an increase in fluid absorption.

The most serious adverse reactions are constipation and ischemic colitis, and therapy must be discontinued immediately in patients who develop those symptoms.

Other adverse reactions include nausea and vomiting, GI discomfort and pain, diarrhea, flatulence, hemorrhoids, and others.

Alosetron may suppress intestinal relaxation leading to ischemic colitis in susceptible individuals.

Alosetron is approved for resistant diarrhoea-predominant irritable bowel syndrome in female patients.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics 13th edition, Page no. 934

choices.text: Screening of close relatives for risk of arrhythmias

questions.text: A 18 year old athlete fell while running and died suddenly. The cut-section of autopsy specimen is shown. Which of the following is correct about the condition?
questions.solution:
The patient in the given question has HCM. They are at high risk of developing ventricular arrhythmias and sudden cardiac death. 80% have mutations in the MYH7 or MYBPC3 gene.

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is characterized by age-dependent and incomplete penetrance. Ventricular hypertrophy is rarely present at birth and usually develops later in life. Women appear to have lower penetrance of sarcomere mutations and an older age at hypertrophic cardiomyopathy diagnosis but increased rates of heart failure and mortality. Screening of family members should begin in adolescence and extend through adulthood.

questions.text: 10-year-old child presented with hemiballismus with sudden onset wild flailing movement arm and leg. Which part is affected?
questions.solution: The involuntary movement described is hemiballismus. Lesion is in sub thalamic nucleus. 30-40% lesion is in putamen, thalamus or parietal cortex

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman gives a history of sharp pain in the lower abdomen for 2 days every month, approximately 2 weeks before the menses. The most probable etiology for her pain is:
questions.solution:
A female giving history of sharp pain in lower abdomen, every month, 2 weeks before the menstruation suggests mittelschmerz as the diagnosis.

Mittelschmerz is synonymous to painful ovulation. Pain is associated with rupture of ovarian follicle at the time of ovulation

questions.text: Barr body is absent in which of the following karyotypes?
questions.solution:
The Barr body is absent in individuals with a karyotype of 45 XO, which is characteristic of Turner's syndrome. Turner's syndrome, a condition that affects only females, results when one of the X chromosomes (sex chromosomes) is missing or partially missing.

Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 20th Edition, Page Number-803.

questions.text: Which of the following is the earliest lesion of Crohn's disease?
questions.solution:
The earliest lesion of Crohn's disease is the aphthous ulcer. These ulcers may progress, and multiple lesions often coalesce into elongated, serpentine ulcers oriented along the axis of the bowel.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page Number 800-801.

questions.text: A patient presented with a history of snakebite 4 hours ago along with ptosis, paralysis and external ophthalmoplegia. On examination, the bite mark cannot be visualized and there is no swelling of the limb. Most probable species implicated is:
questions.solution:
These signs and symptoms point towards a krait bite. The signs and symptoms are of a neurotoxic snake bite. Since bite mark cannot be visualized and there is no swelling of the limb, it must be common krait because fang marks are not visible in common krait as krait has very short fangs and there is no local swelling or necrosis. A common krait bite will often be missed due to its painless nature.

Vipers have hemotoxic (vasculotoxic) venom.

Sea snakes have myotoxic venom.

Reference: Review of Forensic medicine and Toxicology by Gautam Biswas, 5th Edition, Page Number-580.

questions.text: Dalen-Fuchs nodules are associated with:
questions.solution:
• Dalen-Fuchs nodules are small, yellow-white excrescences located between Bruch's membrane and the retinal pigment epithelium.
  • They are associated with sympathetic ophthalmia and Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada syndrome.
  • Sympathetic ophthalmia (SO), also called spared eye injury, is a diffuse granulomatous inflammation of the uveal layer of both eyes following trauma to one eye.

Sympathetic Ophthalmia

  • Bilateral granulomatous non suppurative pan uveitis after penetrating injury to ciliary body (Danger area of eye).
  • Occurs between 2 weeks to 3 months after injury, but cases are seen as early as 1 week and late as 10 years also.
  • Symptom - Loss of accommodation, photophobia
  • Signs - Retrolental flare (inflammation behind lens) 1st sign
  • DALEN FUCH NODULE: Yellow spots throughout retina( aggregation of epithelioid cells on retinal pigment epithelium)
  • Treatment - Systemic steroids and immunosuppressive agents in high dose.
  • Best prophylaxis - Enucleation of traumatic non seeing eye. (Evisceration is contraindicated)

questions.text: Births in India must be registered within:
questions.solution:
The correct answer is option C: 21 days. In India, births must be registered within 21 days of their occurrence.

21 days (Option C):

  • The Registration of Births and Deaths Act, 1969, mandates that births in India must be registered within 21 days of their occurrence.
  • This time frame allows sufficient time for parents or guardians to register the birth of a child with the appropriate authorities, ensuring that the child's birth is officially recorded and legally recognised.

Why the other options are not correct:

7 days (Option A):

  • While it is advisable to register births promptly, the requirement in India is to register births within 21 days, not within 7 days.
  • Allowing 21 days provides flexibility for parents or guardians who may face logistical challenges or delays in completing the registration process.

14 days (Option B):

  • Similar to the previous option, the requirement in India is to register births within 21 days, not within 14 days.
  • Extending the registration period to 21 days ensures that parents or guardians have adequate time to complete the necessary paperwork and submit the registration to the relevant authorities.

1 month (Option D):

  • While registering births within 1 month may be permissible in some jurisdictions, the requirement in India is stricter, with births mandated to be registered within 21 days.
  • Shortening the registration period to 21 days helps ensure timely and accurate record-keeping, facilitating the provision of essential services and benefits to the child and their family.

In summary, option C (21 days) is the correct answer as it reflects the requirement mandated by the Registration of Births and Deaths Act, 1969, in India. Registering births within this timeframe is essential for maintaining accurate demographic records and ensuring that children receive the necessary legal recognition and entitlements from birth.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with infertility and a palpable pelvic mass. Her CA-125 level is 90 mIU/mL. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
CA-125

  • This is a non-specific tumor marker
  • CA-125 is a glycoprotein which is normally not produced by ovarian epithelium but may be produced by both malignant and benign epithelial ovarian tumors.
  • Cut off level of CA-125 is < 35 U/mL.
  • Thus, Ca-125 levels, can be raised in all the four options, given in the question.
  • Palpable mass may also be present in all the four conditions.
  • Infertility is a feature of endometriosis and tuberculosis. But for ovarian cancers, infertility (due to use of ovulation inducing drugs) is a risk factor, not a feature or presenting symptom.
  • Coming to age: Patient is 35 years old.
  • Age of 35 years favors endometrioma (endometriosis) the most.
  • Peak incidence of invasive epithelial ovarian cancer (most common ovarian cancer) is at 56-60 years of age and for border line tumor average age is 46 years approximately. (Novak, 14th edition, page-1466) Patient with tuberculosis are in their twenties commonly, the maximum age incidence at diagnosis being 28 years.
  • Also in tuberculosis, CA 125 has least significance as it is neither used for diagnosis nor for follow up.
  • Thus, based on age and infertility → the most probable diagnosis is endometrioma/endometriosis.
  • Our answer is further supported by following lines from - Textbook of Gynae by Sheila Balakrishnan, 1st Edition, Page-185. Serum ca 125

"This is useful in post-menopausal women where a high level may indicate malignancy. In the reproductive age group, the predictive value is not good as the marker may be raised in endometriosis".

In young females, if the value of Ca-125 is >200 IU/mL, it is considered to indicate malignancy.

Reference: Novak Gynecology, 14th Edition, Page Number 1466, 1146, 1147.

questions.text: A 8 year old girl presented with multiple hypopigmented scaly lesions on the face. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Pityriasis alba is a common, benign skin disorder occurring predominantly in children and adolescents. The name refers to its appearance: pityriasis refers to its fine scales and alba to its pale color (hypopigmentation).

Most patients have a history of atopy, and pityriasis alba may be a minor manifestation of atopic dermatitis.

Pityriasis alba is most common in children aged three to 16 years, with 90% of cases occurring in children younger than 12 years

It is characterized by ill-defined macules and patches (or thin plaques), round or oval, often with mild scaling, and sometimes with mild pruritus.

They are most commonly located on the face (especially the cheeks)

Pityriasis alba resolves spontaneously, with a gradual return of normal skin pigmentation.

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, chapter 39, page 39.25

questions.text: Black foot disease is caused by:
questions.solution:
Black foot disease is caused due to chronic poisoning by Arsenic.

Blackfoot disease is a characteristic vascular disease associated with long-term exposure to inorganic arsenic. It occurred in areas of Taiwan with elevated arsenic in drinking water. The patients suffer severe systemic arteriosclerosis with black, mummified dry foot-gangrene in severe cases.

Signs & symptoms of Chronic Arsenic Poisoning:

  • Earliest sign is emaciation.
  • Catarrhal changes – Rhinitis, lacrimation, conjunctivitis, bronchial catarrh.
  • Hyperpigmentation of palms and soles is seen. It mimics Addison’s disease.
  • Hyperkeratosis of the palm and soles.
  • Rashes resembling fading measles.
  • Raindrop brown pigmentation.
  • Black foot disease leads to a gangrenous change.
  • Aldrich-Mee’s lines (leukonychia) are seen (Multiple, transverse parallel white lines in the nails. Takes about 30 days after first exposure. Also seen in thallium poisoning).
  • Cancer (A precancerous lesion called Bowen’s disease, Basal cell carcinoma, small cell carcinoma, Ca lung and Ca bladder).

Reference: https://www.sciencedirect.com › topics › blackfoot-disease

questions.text: Economic benefits of any program are compared with the cost incurred in-
questions.solution:
• Cost benefit analysis (a): Cost benefit analysis is a method used to compare the economic benefits of a program or project with the costs incurred. It involves quantifying both the benefits and costs in monetary terms and then comparing them to determine whether the benefits outweigh the costs. This analysis helps decision-makers evaluate the efficiency and feasibility of implementing a program by considering its potential economic returns.

Explanation for why not the other options:

  • Cost-effective analysis (b): Cost-effective analysis, also known as cost-effectiveness analysis, compares the relative costs and outcomes of different interventions or programs. It aims to identify the most efficient way to achieve a specific outcome by comparing the cost per unit of outcome across different options. While cost-effective analysis is related to economic evaluation, it focuses specifically on comparing the efficiency of achieving outcomes rather than considering broader economic benefits.
  • Cost accounting (c): Cost accounting involves the process of recording, classifying, and analyzing costs associated with the production of goods or services within an organization. It is primarily used for internal management purposes to control costs, optimize resource allocation, and make informed decisions. Unlike cost benefit analysis, cost accounting does not involve comparing costs with economic benefits outside the organization.
  • Network analysis (d): Network analysis is a method used to analyze complex systems of interconnected elements, such as transportation networks, communication networks, or project management networks. It involves techniques like critical path method (CPM) and program evaluation and review technique (PERT) to model and optimize the flow of activities or resources within the network. While network analysis can be used to optimize resource allocation and improve efficiency, it is not specifically focused on comparing costs and benefits as in cost benefit analysis.

Therefore, option (a) is the correct choice as it directly relates to comparing economic benefits with incurred costs, which is the essence of cost benefit analysis. The other options are related to different methods or concepts in economic evaluation and analysis, but they do not specifically involve comparing costs with economic benefits.

questions.text: A 19-year-old patient complains of primary amenorrhea. She has well- developed breasts and pubic hair, but on examination, there is an absence of the uterus and vagina. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the case of primary amenorrhea, well-developed secondary sexual characteristics, and absence of the uterus and vagina is Mullerian agenesis (Mayer- Rokitansky-Kuster-Hauser syndrome). This condition is characterized by the congenital absence of the uterus and upper part of the vagina. The well-developed breasts and pubic hair indicate normal ovarian function, distinguishing it from conditions like gonadal dysgenesis or Klinefelter syndrome.

questions.text: A 65 year old man came to medicine department for regular check up with history of type 2 diabetes mellitus. On investigation his reports shows LDL-C levels of 195 mg/dL. Which of the following is the best option to lower his LDL-C and decrease the risk of acute cardiovascular events in this patient?
questions.solution:
Rosuvastatin, an HMG CoA reductase inhibitor (statin), is the most effective option for lowering LDL-C, achieving reductions of up to 60% from baseline levels. Greater LDL-CH reduction can be obtained in severe hypercholesterolaemia; partly due to its longer persistence in the plasma. In patients with raised TG levels, rosuvastatin raises HDL-CH by 10–15% (greater rise than other statins).

Statins are the primary modality for reducing ASCVD risk when drug therapy is indicated.

Fenofibrate is more effective at lowering triglyceride levels or raising HDL-C. Colesevelam can reduce LDL-C, but not as effectively as statins. Ezetimibe lowers LDL-C modestly compared to the LDL-C reduction achieved by statins.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, Page no. 685

In this context, the most probable diagnosis is a pituitary adenoma, and a CT scan of the head is expected to reveal this tumor. questions.text: A patient was admitted with features suggestive of chronic meningitis. CSF CBNAAT showed evidence of Drug sensitive TB. HIV also was tested positive. What should be done?
questions.solution: Initiation of ART and/or anti-TB therapy may be associated with clinical deterioration due to immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS) reactions. These are most common in patients initiating both treatments at the same time, may occur as early as 1 week after initiation of ART therapy, and are seen more frequently in patients with advanced HIV disease. For these reasons it is recommended that initiation of ART be delayed in antiretroviral-naive patients with CD4 counts >50 cells/μL until 2-4 weeks following the initiation of treatment for TB. For patients with lower CD4 counts the benefits of more immediate ART Outweigh the risks of IRIS, and ART should be started as soon as possible in those patients.

questions.text: A patient's blood pressure increases from 100 mmHg to 120 mmHg. If the patient's baseline glomerular filtration rate (GFR) is 120 mL/min, and the patient has intact renal autoregulation, what is the expected change in GFR?
questions.solution:
The myogenic mechanism of renal autoregulation helps maintain a constant GFR by regulating the diameter of the afferent arteriole in response to changes in blood pressure. When blood pressure increases, the afferent arteriole constricts, limiting the increase in GFR. Therefore, if a patient's blood pressure increases from 100 mmHg to 120 mmHg and the patient has intact renal autoregulation, the expected change in GFR would be no change, and GFR will remain unchanged at 120 mL/min.

Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th Edition, Page Number-319.

questions.text: Identify the bone shown in the image
questions.solution:
The image shows the incus, which is the second ossicle in the middle ear. The incus is a small, anvil-shaped bone that connects the malleus (hammer) to the stapes (stirrup) and plays a crucial role in transmitting sound vibrations from the tympanic membrane to the inner ear.

Other options:

A. Malleus: The malleus, also known as the "hammer," is one of the three small bones (ossicles) located in the middle ear. It is the outermost ossicle and is attached to the tympanic membrane (eardrum). The Malleus is responsible for transmitting sound vibrations from the tympanic membrane to the next ossicle, the incus.

C. Stapes: The stapes, also known as the "stirrup," is the innermost ossicle in the middle ear. It is the smallest bone in the human body. The stapes is connected to the incus on one end and the oval window (a membrane-covered opening to the inner ear) on the other end. It plays a crucial role in transmitting sound vibrations from the middle ear to the fluid-filled cochlea of the inner ear.

D. Hyoid: The hyoid bone is a unique U-shaped bone located in the neck, just above the larynx (voice box). It is the only bone in the human body that does not directly articulate with any other bone. The hyoid bone serves as an attachment site for several muscles involved in swallowing and speaking.

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Surgery by P L Dhingra, 7th Edition, Page Number-9.

choices.text: Most commonly occurs through the superior lumbar triangle
Lumbar hernias can be congenital or acquired
Less commonly occurs through the grynfeltt triangle

questions.text: All of the following statements are true for the lumbar hernias except:
questions.solution:
• Lumbar hernias can be congenital or acquired after an operation on the flank and occurs in the lumbar region of the posterior abdominal wall.
  • Most primary lumbar hernias occur through the inferior lumbar triangle (Petit triangle) bounded below by the crest of the ilium, laterally by the external oblique muscle and medially by latissimus dorsi.
  • Less commonly, the sac comes through the superior lumbar triangle (grynfeltt triangle), which is bounded by the twelfth rib above, medially by sacrospinalis and laterally by the posterior border of the internal oblique muscle.
  • Primary lumbar hernias are rare, but may be mimicked by incisional hernias arising through flank incisions for renal operations, or through incisions for bone grafts harvested from the iliac crest.
  • The natural history is for these hernias to increase in size and surgery is recommended.
  • Lumbar hernias can be approached by open or laparoscopic surgery. The defects can be difficult to close with sutures and mesh is recommended.

The only natural weaknesses caused by inadequate muscular strength are the lumbar triangles (see Lumbar hernia) and the posterior wall of the inguinal canal.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery, chapter: 64, Edition: 28th, Pg: 1076

questions.text: Vitamin D deficiency can cause which one among the following?
questions.solution:
• Hypocalcemia or Vitamin D deficiency in pregnancy gives rise to spoke-like opacities which are called riders. It is a type of zonular cataract.
  • CONGENITAL AND DEVELOPMENTAL CATARACT
  • This is due to disturbance in the growth and development of the lens. Disturbance in development during the period of gestation leads to congenital cataract and usually affects the embryonic or foetal nucleus.
  • Developmental cataract is due to disturbance in development after birth and hence affects the infantile or adult nucleus and cortex

ZONULAR/ LAMELLAR CATARACT


  • Punctate cataract: It consists of minute white dots throughout the lens but causes no visual disturbance. It is called blue dot cataract. It is the most common type of congenital cataract.
  • Zonular or lamellar cataract: This is the most common type of congenital cataract associated with diminished vision. A zone in the foetal nucleus is usually affected. Hypocalcemia in pregnancy is an important cause.
  • Nuclear cataract. This usually affects the embryonic nucleus. Rubella in pregnancy is an important cause.
  • Coronary cataract. It usually occurs around puberty and is characterized by opacities in the periphery of the lens.
  • Anterior polar cataract
  • Posterior polar cataract

questions.text: The corpus luteum secretes?
questions.solution:
The corpus luteum secretes progesterone, the level of which starts rising. The hormone progesterone has two functions.

In the first place, it stimulates the endometrium to undergo secretory hypertrophy, and secondly, it inhibits further production of LH by the anterior pituitary.

Natural estrogens are C18 steroids, the main source of which are the theca and granulosa cells of the Graafian follicles and corpus luteum, while the adrenal cortex is the secondary source of supply.

Hence, corpus luteum secretes both estrogen and progesterone.

questions.text: In an Asian country with a population of 6 million people, 60000 deaths occurred in the year 2005. These included 30,000 deaths from cholera in 100,000 people who were sick with cholera. The cause specific mortality rate and Case Fatality Rate from cholera in 2005 are respectively-

No:of deaths from cholera/Mid Year Population x 1000

30,000/60,00,000 X 1000 = 5 per 1000

Case Fatality Rate of cholera=

Total no: of deaths due to cholera/Total no: of cases of cholera x 100

30,000/1,00,000 x 100 = 30 per 100 or 30%

Primary survey includes:

  • c- Control of Exsanguinating hemorrhage
  • A-Airway with spine control
  • B- Breathing and ventilation
  • C-Circulation and Hemorrhage Control
  • D- Disability ( Glassgow coma Scale)
  • E- Exposure

In management of Hemorrhage control ; Bailey and Love writes in page number 356;

  • Traditionally Chest and Pelvic radiographs are obtained early in the assessment of polytrauma to look for major bleeding in the intrathoracic or in the pelvis.
  • A FAST if available also can be used in this phase if immediately available to locate any major source of bleeding.
  • Whole Body CT scan is the gold standard in patients admitted with multiple injuries or deranged physiology. There is no role of selective body CT scanning as per the history in severe injury.
  • A provisional HOT REPORT can be obtained in 10 minutes to identify any life threatening pathology, a more detailed report is obtained in 30-60 minutes.
  • The Traditional Chest and Pelvic radiographs are increasingly omitted by a rapid WBCT which is now available in most trauma centres, where resuscitation will be done along with WBCT being done simultaneously.

Reference: Bailey 28th Edition page 355-357

questions.text: A patient presented with a progressively growing swelling for the last 2 years. On examination, it was dense, mobile and nodular as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of a progressively growing, dense, mobile, and nodular swelling in the parotid region is highly suggestive of a parotid gland tumor. The parotid gland is the most common site for salivary gland tumors, and the majority of them are benign.

Other options :

  • Jaw tumor:Jaw tumors are rare, but they can occur. They can be benign or malignant, and they can present as a painless, slow-growing mass.
  • Dermoid cyst:Dermoid cysts are benign tumors that are made up of skin tissue. They can occur anywhere on the body, including the face and neck.
  • Sebaceous cyst:Sebaceous cysts are also benign tumors, but they are made up of sebaceous glands. They can occur anywhere on the body, but they are most common on the face and scalp.

Reference: Textbook of ENT and Head & Neck Surgery by Hazarika, 3rd Edition, Page Number-581.

questions.text: In a case of recurrent spontaneous abortion, which of the following investigations is unwanted?
questions.solution:
In the evaluation of recurrent early pregnancy loss, testing for TORCH infections (Toxoplasmosis, Other agents, Rubella, Cytomegalovirus, Herpes simplex) is unwanted because these infections are not a common cause of recurrent abortions. Chromosomal abnormalities are the most common cause of repeated first-trimester loss. Karyotyping of both partners is recommended in cases of recurrent miscarriage to identify any chromosomal anomalies. Other investigative measures include assessing the intrauterine cavity, thyroid function tests, and testing for antiphospholipid antibodies. These tests help identify potential causes of recurrent miscarriage.

Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 7th Edition, Page Number 149,1302

questions.text: A 5 year old child presented with multiple tense bullae on the body, associated with itching. What is the diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
• Clinical features of linear IgA bullous disease/ CBDC:
  • May occur anywhere on the body
  • In children, usually found on the lower abdomen, thighs, and groin
  • In adults, the limbs, face, and truck are more commonly affected
  • Mucosal involvement can be seen in one-third of patients
  • C/F : Round or oval filled with clear fluid, vesicles and bullae
  • Typically found in rings (annular lesions) in children - new blisters tend to arise in a ring around an existing blister known as the 'string of beads' sign / 'cluster of jewels' or 'crown of jewels'.
  • The lesions are very pruritic
  • Management: Patients respond to dapsone (DOC).

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition Chapter 50 , Page 50.33

questions.text: Which of the following amino acids is excreted in urine in the maple syrup urine disease?
questions.solution:
• Maple syrup urine disease (MSUD) is a disorder involving the accumulation of branched-chain amino acids (BCAAs), including leucine, isoleucine, and valine. In MSUD, there is a deficiency in the branched-chain alpha-keto acid dehydrogenase enzyme complex, leading to the characteristic maple syrup odor of urine and neurological symptoms.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 30th Edition, Page Number 309-310.

questions.text: Which of the following is an irreversible method of contraception?
questions.solution:
The contraceptive methods may be broadly grouped into two classes

  1. Spacing methods and
  2. Terminal methods,

1) Spacing methods:

  1. Barrier methods
    1. Physical methods
    2. Chemical methods
    3. Combined methods
  2. Intrauterine devices
  3. Hormonal methods
  4. Post-conceptional methods
  5. Miscellaneous.

2) Terminal methods

  1. Male sterilization
  2. Female sterilization.

STERILIZATION

Sterilization offers many advantages over other contraceptive methods.

  • It is a one-time method: it does not require sustained motivation of the user for its effectiveness;
  • Provides the most effective protection against pregnancy:
  • The risk of complications is small if the procedure is performed according to accepted medical standards
  • It is most cost-effective.
  • Permanent method
  • In females: It is called as tubectomy
  • In males, it is called as vasectomy

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition

questions.text: A gravida 3 female with a history of 2 previous 2nd-trimester abortions presents at 22 weeks of gestation with funneling of the cervix and short cevix. The most appropriate management would be:
questions.solution:
In a case of cervical incompetence (funneling of the cervix) during the second trimester, the most appropriate management is the application of a McDonald cervical cerclage (stitch).

This procedure involves placing a stitch (suture) around the cervix to provide mechanical support and prevent further cervical dilation. This helps to reduce the risk of recurrent second-trimester pregnancy loss.

questions.text: When a woman who has been on a low-sodium diet for 8 days is given an intravenous injection of captopril, a drug that inhibits angiotensin-converting enzyme, one would expect
questions.solution:
• Angiotensin II produces arteriolar constriction and a rise in systolic and diastolic blood pressure. It is one of the most potent vasoconstrictors known, being four to eight times as active as norepinephrine on a weight basis in normal individuals.
  • However, its pressor activity is decreased in Na + - depleted individuals.
  • In these conditions, circulating angiotensin II down-regulates the angiotensin receptors in vascular smooth muscle.
  • In Na+ depleted individuals inhibitors of Angiotensin II ( Captopril) leads to better fall in peripheral resistance.

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 24th Edition Ch 38 Pg: 704

questions.text: In extremely premature babies, which of the following cells are deficient?
questions.solution:
Extremely premature babies, born before 28 weeks of gestation, have a low number as well as function of type II alveolar cells. This leads to reduced surfactant production, and can lead to RDS in the patient.

Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 20th Edition, Page Number-449.

questions.text:
Which of the following is/are objective tests of hearing?
A. Tympanometry
B. Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry
C. Otoacoustic Emissions
D. Pure Tone Audiometry
questions.solution:
Correct answer is option C: Tympanometry, Otoacoustic Emissions, and Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry (BERA) are objective tests of hearing.

a. Tympanometry: Tympanometry is an objective test that measures the movement of the eardrum (tympanic membrane) in response to changes in air pressure. It helps evaluate the middle ear function and detects conditions such as fluid accumulation or eustachian tube dysfunction.

b. Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry (BERA): BERA, also known as Auditory Brainstem Response (ABR), is an objective test that measures the electrical activity of the auditory nerve and brainstem in response to sound stimuli. It is commonly used to assess hearing in infants and individuals who are unable to participate in conventional behavioral hearing tests

c. Otoacoustic Emissions (OAE): OAEs are sounds generated by the inner ear in response to external auditory stimuli. They can be measured using a sensitive microphone placed in the ear canal. OAEs are used to assess the function of the cochlea and are particularly helpful in screening for hearing loss in newborns.

d. Pure Tone Audiometry: Pure Tone Audiometry is a subjective test that relies on the patient's response to pure tone sounds of different frequencies and intensities. The patient indicates when they hear the tones, and the results are plotted on an audiogram. It is not an objective test.

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Surgery by P L Dhingra, 7th Edition, Page Number-25.

questions.text: A young female presents with a left sided throbbing headache. She also has nausea, vomiting, aura and phonophobia. What is the best treatment for immediate relief?
questions.solution:
The question deals with treatment of an acute attack of migraine. Among the given options , only Sumartriptan is used for aborting an acute episode. The others are used for prophylaxis of migraine.

The drugs used in acute migraine

  1. Acetaminophen
  2. NSAIDS
  3. 5HT 1B/1D receptor agonists -Triptans
  4. CGRP receptor agonists-Oral-Rimegepant,Ubrogepant
  5. 5HT1F receptor agonists-Ditans
  6. Dopamine receptor agonists - Metoclopramide

questions.text: A primigravida at 36 weeks of gestation reported to the labor room with central placenta previa with heavy bleeding per vaginum. The fetal heart rate was normal at the time of examination. The best management option for her is:
questions.solution:
In the case of a primigravida at 36 weeks with central placenta previa and heavy bleeding, the best management option is immediate caesarean section. Placenta previa is a condition where the placenta partially or completely covers the cervix, and central placenta previa, especially with heavy bleeding, is a situation where vaginal delivery is contraindicated. The risk of massive hemorrhage poses a threat to both the mother and the fetus. Therefore, immediate operative intervention through caesarean section is the recommended approach to avoid maternal death.

Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 7th Edition, Page Number 249, 250, 337, 339.

questions.text:
Muscle excitation contraction coupling is the sequential phenomena which involves various steps. Arrange them in the correct sequential order.
1. Discharge of Motor neurons.
2. Release of neurotransmitters at the motor end plate.
3. Binding of neurotransmitters to the receptor and generation of action potential.
4. Spread of depolarization in the T-tubules and release of calcium from the terminal sarcoplasmic reticulum, and its binding to troponin C.
5. Formation of cross linkages and muscle contraction occurs.
questions.solution:
The correct sequence for muscle excitation-contraction coupling is as follows:

  1. Discharge of Motor neurons.
  2. Release of neurotransmitters at the motor end plate.
  3. Binding of neurotransmitters to the receptor and generation of action potential.
  4. Spread of depolarization in the T-tubules and release of calcium from the terminal sarcoplasmic reticulum, and its binding to troponin C.
  5. Formation of cross linkages and muscle contraction occurs.

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 25th Edition, Page Number 99-120.

questions.text: Which one of the following congenital malformations of the fetus can be diagnosed in the first trimester by ultrasound?
questions.solution:
Anencephaly, a congenital malformation characterized by the absence of a major portion of the brain, skull, and scalp, can be diagnosed in the first trimester by ultrasound. Skilled ultrasound examination can reveal the absence of the cranial vault, allowing for early detection. Other conditions like microcephaly and holoprosencephaly may be diagnosed later in the pregnancy.

Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 7th Edition, Page Number-1120.

questions.text: Jugular notch lies at which of the following levels?
questions.solution:
Suprasternal or jugular notch:

  • It is felt just above the superior border of the manubrium between the sternal ends of the clavicles.
  • It is also known as the interclavicular notch.
  • It lies at the level of the lower border of the body of the second thoracic vertebra.
  • The trachea can be palpated in this notch.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia: Human Anatomy, Volume-1, 8th Edition, Page Number-209.

questions.solution: Best way to calculate gestational age, when LMP is unknown in 1st trimester is CRL by USG. Calculation of EDD by Naegele's rule = 1st day of LMP = 9 months + 7d (280 d) but if h/o OCP +, ovulation is unpredictable, so Naegele’s rule is not applicable, & best method is dating scan by CRL on TVS.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents to the clinic with complaints of heavy menstrual bleeding and frequent nosebleeds. She reports a history of similar symptoms in her mother and sister. On physical examination, there is no evidence of petechiae or ecchymoses, but there is tenderness on deep palpation of the lower abdomen. Laboratory tests reveal a prolonged bleeding time and a normal platelet count. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Von Willebrand disease is a common inherited bleeding disorder characterized by a deficiency or dysfunction of von Willebrand factor, a protein critical for platelet adhesion and aggregation. Clinical features include heavy menstrual bleeding, frequent nosebleeds, and prolonged bleeding time. Unlike some other bleeding disorders, platelet count is typically normal.

Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th Edition, Page Number 477-487.

questions.text: Which of the following is a disease of the branched-chain amino acids?
questions.solution:

questions.text:
In an orthopedic ward of the hospital, all postoperative patients developed stitch abscess. Upon further inquiry, it was observed that it was an outbreak of one bacteria. They all were hospital-acquired infections. Later, it was discovered that all cases of stitch infections were caused by Pseudomonas.
Pseudomonas is which type of bacteria?
questions.solution:
Pseudomonas is a gram-negative, non-capsulated, non-spore-forming bacterium that is an obligate aerobe (strict aerobe). It is known for causing opportunistic infections, particularly in hospital settings.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Page Number 919-925.

questions.text: 50 year old alcoholic patient presents with painful and swollen 1st MTP. Aspiration reveals leukocyte count > 2000 cell/mm3. There is no history of travel, dysuria, dysentery, sexual contact in patients. BUN and serum uric acid level is normal. Clinical Diagnosis is?
questions.solution: History of alcoholism with pain and swelling in the First metatarsophalangeal joint suggests diagnosis of Acute gout. The absence of travel history, dysuria, dysentery or sexual conduct rules out other options like septic arthritis, reactive arthritis.

questions.text: Most appropriate route for adrenaline use in patients with cardiac arrest is:
questions.solution:
Adrenaline is commonly used to stimulate the heart in case of cardiac arrest. The most appropriate route for adrenaline administration in this context is intravenous (IV) injection. It is typically administered via IV in conjunction with an external cardiac massage.

For IV injection, the 1 in 1000 solution of adrenaline should be diluted appropriately and slowly injected into a central vein, such as the jugular vein, especially in the absence of circulation.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page Number-151.

questions.text: What is the investigation of choice for haemorrhagic meckel's diverticulum?
questions.solution:
Meckel's diverticulum

  • The vast majority of Meckel's diverticulae are asymptomatic and Meckel's diverticulum is notoriously difficult to see with contrast Meckel's diverticulum may, however, present clinically in the following ways:
  • Haemorrhage.
    • If gastric mucosa is present, peptic ulceration can occur and present as painless dark rectal bleeding or melaena.
    • If the stomach, duodenum and colon are excluded as a source of bleeding by endoscopy, radioisotope scanning with technetium-99m may demonstrate a Meckel's diverticulum.
  • Diverticulitis.
    • Meckel's diverticulitis presents like appendicitis, although if perforation occurs the presentation may resemble a perforated duodenal ulcer.
  • Intussusception.
    • A Meckel's diverticulum can be the lead point for ileoileal or ileocolic intussusception.
  • Chronic ulceration.
    • Pain is felt around the umbilicus, as the site of the diverticulum is midgut in origin.
  • Intestinal obstruction.
    • A band between the apex of the diverticulum and the umbilicus (also part of the vitellointestinal duct) may cause obstruction directly, or by predisposing to the development of a volvulus around it.
  • Perforation.
    • When found in the course of abdominal surgery, a Meckel's diverticulum can safely be left alone, provided it has a wide mouth and is not thickened. When there is doubt, it can be resected. The finding of a Meckel's diverticulum in an inguinal or femoral hernia has been described as 'Littre's hernia'.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery, chapter: 74, Edition: 28th, Pg: 1312

questions.text: Most common uterine malformation associated with infertility:
questions.solution: Among the anomalies, the only form of malfusion deformity which may lower fertility significantly is a fully septate vagina.

questions.text: A 40-year-old smoker male patient presents with high-grade fever, cough, diarrhea, confusion. Chest X-ray shows bilateral pneumonitis. Which pathogenic agent is suspected?
questions.solution:
Legionella can cause severe pneumonia with bilateral involvement, confusion, and extrapulmonary symptoms. Legionella pneumonia is associated with a longer incubation period and can be severe, especially in immunosuppressed hosts.

  • Pneumonia caused by Legionella is clinically and radiographically similar to other forms of pneumonia.
  • Suggestive clinical features include
    1. Gastrointestinal symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea
    2. Hyponatremia
    3. Elevated hepatic transaminases
    4. C-reactive protein levels >100 mg/L
    5. Failure to respond to treatment for pneumonia with beta-lactam
    6. monotherapy

questions.text: Which of the following is a sensory branch of the anterior division of the mandibular nerve?
questions.solution:
Branches of the mandibular nerve:

  • From the main trunk:
    • Meningeal branch
    • Nerve to the medial pterygoid.
  • From the anterior trunk:
    • A sensory branch—the buccal nerve.
    • Motor branches—the masseteric and deep temporal nerves and the nerve to the lateral pterygoid.
  • From the posterior trunk:
    • Auriculotemporal nerve
    • Lingual nerve
    • Inferior alveolar nerve

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia: Human Anatomy, Volume-3, 8th Edition, Page Number-136.

questions.text: During sudden hyperflexion of the thigh over the abdomen (McRoberts manoeuvre), which of the following nerves is commonly involved?
questions.solution:
McRoberts' manoeuvre is a technique used in obstetrics, involving hyperflexion of the thighs toward the abdomen during childbirth. While it is a highly effective method to address shoulder dystocia, overzealous use of McRoberts' manoeuvre has been associated with complications. In some cases, this manoeuvre can lead to separation of the maternal pubic symphysis and injury to the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh. This nerve injury is a known risk, and clinicians should exercise caution during the application of McRoberts' manoeuvre to prevent such complications.

Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 23rd Edition, Page Number-487

questions.text: Thyroxine is synthesized from:
questions.solution:
• Thyroxine (T4) is a thyroid hormone synthesized from the amino acid tyrosine.
  • The synthesis involves iodination of tyrosine residues within thyroglobulin, a precursor protein stored in the thyroid gland. This process occurs in the follicular cells of the thyroid gland and is crucial for the production of the functional thyroid hormones.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 30th Edition, Page Number 319-320.

questions.solution:
