No: of patients alive after 5 yrs X 100

No: of cases diagnosed/treated

Survival rate can be used to measure survival rate of disease or treatment

questions.text: Pulmonary eosinophilia is seen in all the following parasitic infections except:
questions.solution:
Pulmonary eosinophilia is commonly associated with parasitic infections. Babesiosis is caused by babesia parasites, which primarily infect red blood cells and are not known to cause pulmonary eosinophilia. Conditions such as hookworm infection, strongyloidiasis, and visceral larva migrans are, however, associated with eosinophilic infiltrates in the lungs.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Page Number-2120.

questions.text: A 35-year-old pregnant woman with a history of genital herpes presents at term. She has active genital lesions at the time of labor. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution: In the presence of active genital lesions at the time of labor in a woman with a history of genital herpes, cesarean section is the most appropriate management to reduce the risk of neonatal herpes transmission.

questions.text: A child born by normal vaginal delivery has repeated attacks of flexion of neck over the trunk jerks in hands. EEG shows hypsarrhythmia. What is the drug of choice?
questions.solution:
The question deals with infantile epileptic spasms.

Clinical features

  1. Briefly sustained flexion & extension of proximal & truncal muscles.
  2. EEG-Hypsarrhythmia-diffuse, giant slow waves in a chaotic background of irregular multifocal sharp waves and spikes.
  3. During the spasm the EEG background will be markedly suppressed.

Treatment: IV ACTH

questions.text: A farmer presented with a lesion as shown in the image. Bedside stain from granules showed gram negative organisms. What will be the appropriate treatment
questions.solution:
• Image shows swelling on the foot with discharging sinuses. Diagnosis of mycetoma
  • Gram negative hyphae seen in eumycetoma while gram positive filamentous bacteria seen in actinomycetoma.
  • Since gram negative structures seen here - diagnosis of Eumycetoma
  • Mycetoma is a chronic, granulomatous disease of the skin and subcutaneous tissue, which sometimes involves muscle, bone, and neighbouring organs.
  • Follows a penetrating trauma with thorns, wood splinters, or implantation with solid objects.
  • It typically affects the lower extremities. The hand is the next most common location, predominately occurs in farm workers
  • It is characterized by triad of painless swelling, sinuses, pus discharge containing granules (aggregates of the causative organisms)
  • Treatment for mycetoma is generally a combination of medical and surgical therapy. Medical therapy is often prolonged, lasting for months to years. While medical therapy alone may be sufficient for actinomycetoma, surgery is generally needed for eumycetoma.
  • Eumycetoma : surgical removal is usually done first. The most successful treatment option for eumycetomas is itraconazole 200 mg twice daily. Given for a year atleast
  • Actinomycetoma : respond to antibiotics, The combination of amikacin with cotrimoxazole (so-called Welsh regimen) is used. Adding rifampin to the Welsh regimen (modified Welsh regimen) allows for remissions without recurrence.
  • Every 3 weeks, periodic audiometric and creatine clearance analysis must be performed. This treatment is maintained for 5-20 weeks 
  • Given for 5-20 weeks

Reference: Rook’s Textbook of Dermatology. 9th Page 32.73

choices.text: It is inherited as autosomal dominant
At least 200 polyps are required for the diagnosis of classic FAP
Prophylactic colectomy is the standard of care
Adenomas may occur in the ampulla of Vater

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP)?
questions.solution:
At least 100 polyps are necessary for a diagnosis of classic FAP, but thousands may be present. FAP is an autosomal dominant disorder, and prophylactic colectomy is the standard of care. Adenomas may occur in the ampulla of Vater.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page Number-812.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman at 38 weeks of gestation presents with severe headache, visual disturbances, and epigastric pain. Blood pressure is elevated (160/110 mm Hg), and laboratory tests show thrombocytopenia, raised LDH, and elevated liver enzymes. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The combination of elevated blood pressure, thrombocytopenia, and elevated liver enzymes are characteristic of HELLP syndrome, a severe form of preeclampsia. This condition requires prompt recognition and management.

The syndrome of hemolysis with a microangiopathic blood smear, elevated liver enzymes, and low platelet count, is more commonly known by the acronym HELLP syndrome in pregnant and postpartum patients. It may represent a complication or progression of severe preeclampsia.

questions.text: Wall of the carotid sinus receives innervation from which of the following nerves?
questions.solution:
Carotid sinus:

  1. The termination of the common carotid artery, or the beginning of the internal carotid artery shows a slight dilatation, known as the carotid sinus.
  2. In this region, the tunica media is thin, but the adventitia is relatively thick and receives a rich innervation from the glossopharyngeal and sympathetic nerves.
  3. The carotid sinus acts as a baroreceptor or pressure receptor and regulates blood pressure.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia: Human Anatomy, Volume-3, 8th Edition, Page Number-109.

questions.text: In UNICEF's GOBI campaign, 'O' stands for-
questions.solution:
UNICEF's GOBI (Growth monitoring, Oral rehydration therapy, Breastfeeding, and Immunization) campaign was launched in the early 1980s to address key issues related to child health and well-being in developing countries. Each letter in the acronym represents a critical intervention or component of child health promotion.

Explanation for why not the other options:

a) Oral contraceptives:

  • While oral contraceptives are important for family planning and reproductive health, they are not part of the UNICEF GOBI campaign, which focuses on child health and development rather than family planning.

c) Obesity:

  • Obesity is a significant health issue, particularly in developed countries, but it is not specifically addressed within the context of the UNICEF GOBI campaign, which primarily targets child health in developing nations.

d) Occupational hazards:

  • Occupational hazards refer to health risks associated with certain types of work environments or occupations. While important for overall public health, occupational hazards are not directly related to the objectives of the UNICEF GOBI campaign, which focuses on child health interventions.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman at 10 weeks of gestation presents with a history of recurrent pregnancy loss. On ultrasound, an empty gestational sac is seen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: An empty gestational sac on ultrasound at 10 weeks of gestation is suggestive of a blighted ovum, where the embryo fails to develop or is reabsorbed, leading to an empty sac. The gestational sac and placenta will grow, but the gestational sac containing the embryo remains empty. It causes a miscarriage in the first trimester of pregnancy.

choices.text: Clinical manifestations can begin at any time after birth

questions.text: A 8 month old baby presented with diarrhea and skin lesions. Which of the following is incorrect about the condition shown below
questions.solution:
• Acrodermatitis enteropathica (AE) is an autosomal recessive condition resulting in severe zinc deficiency.
  • The deficiency is caused by a defect of dietary zinc absorption in the duodenum and jejunum, occurring as a result of mutations in the SLC39A4 ( zinc/iron-regulated transporter like protein (ZIP) family required for zinc uptake)
  • AE usually presents itself during infancy after weaning.
  • The presentation is usually at the time of weaning in infants who are breastfed and earlier when they are formula-fed. In some cases, an infant who is breastfed may present with the manifestations of acrodermatitis enteropathica even before weaning. This could be due to the decreased secretion of zinc into breast milk due to a mutation in the mothers
  • It is characterized by periorificial and acral dermatitis, alopecia, and diarrhea
  • Treatment requires lifelong zinc supplementation.

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology 9th edition, chapter 63, page 63.25

questions.text: A patient who is a known case of C.L.D. with ascites presents with abdominal pain and tenderness. Ascitic tap shows presence of 600 PolyMorphoNuclear cells/mm3. Which of the following is the likely etiology?
questions.solution:
Abdominal pain and tenderness in a C.L.D patient with ascites suggests SBP, if the ascitic fluid analysis shows PolyMorphoNuclear cells>250/mm³. SBP is also seen in ascites due to nephrotic syndrome, heart failure, acute hepatitis. Rare in malignant ascites. SBP is characterized by the culture of a single organism. SBP is due to enteric pathogens- E coli, Klebsiella, Streptococcus, Enterococci.

TB ascites will have ascitic fluid lymphocytosis. AFB smear is 0.3% positive. In patients without cirrhosis an elevated ADA has > 90% sensitivity.

Chylous ascites are seen with milky ascitic fluid with TG>200 mg/dl. It is due to lymphatic disruption occurring with trauma, cirrhosis, tumor, TB or certain congenital abnormalities.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a substrate for gluconeogenesis?
questions.solution: Acetyl CoA cannot be converted to glucose through gluconeogenesis. Gluconeogenesis is a pathway that synthesizes glucose from non-carbohydrate precursors, including glucogenic amino acids, lactate, glycerol, and propionyl CoA. Acetyl CoA is a product of fatty acid oxidation and cannot be converted back into glucose because it lacks a glucogenic precursor.

choices.text: Manual elevation of the presenting part

questions.text: A 26-year-old pregnant woman at 32 weeks of gestation presents with a sudden gush of clear fluid from her vagina. On examination, the cervix is dilated, and the umbilical cord is prolapsed into the vagina. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
In the scenario of umbilical cord prolapse, the most appropriate immediate management is manual elevation of the presenting part to relieve pressure on the cord. This manoeuvre helps prevent compression of the umbilical cord, which can compromise fetal blood flow and oxygenation.

Immediate delivery is the definitive management if the cord prolapse occurs- which is often done by caesarean section.

Ruptured since it is very thin
Unruptured since it is deeply situated
Unruptured since it is highly elastic

questions.text: In case of rape of a young child, the hymen is usually:
questions.solution:
In the case of a young child, the hymen is deeply situated and is usually intact after intercourse.

  • In young children, there are few or no signs of general violence, for the child usually has no idea of what is happening, and is also incapable of resisting.
  • In an older child, typical grasping injuries and bruises from blows may be found.
  • The hymen is deeply situated, and as the vagina is very small, it is impossible for the penetration of the adult organ to take place.
  • Usually, the penis is placed either within the vulva or between the thighs. As such, the hymen is usually intact and there may be little redness and tenderness of the vulva.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology by KS Narayan Reddy, 35th Edition, Page Number-327.

questions.text: An infant was brought to the OPD with complaints of noisy breathing. The stridor was reported to improve on lying prone & suckling of milk. the image of the airway is given below. what type of stridor is expected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Laryngomalacia (Congenital Laryngeal Stridor). It is the most common congenital abnormality of the larynx. It is characterized by excessive flaccidity of supraglottic larynx which is sucked in during inspiration producing stridor and sometimes cyanosis. Stridor is increased on crying but subsides on placing the child in prone position; cry is normal. The condition manifests at birth or soon after, and usually disappears by 2 years of age. Direct laryngoscopy shows elongated epiglottis, curled upon itself (omega-shaped Ω), floppy aryepiglottic folds and prominent arytenoids. Flexible laryngoscope is very useful to make the diagnosis. Laryngomalacia cannot be diagnosed in a paralyzed patient. Mostly, treatment is conservative. Tracheostomy may be required for some cases of severe respiratory obstruction. Supraglottoplasty is required in cases of severe laryngomalacia

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 7TH EDITION, CHAPTER 33, PAGE NO. :333

questions.text: A 34-year-old pregnant woman with a history of type 1 diabetes is at 28 weeks of gestation. What is the most important factor to monitor the antepartum management of this patient?
questions.solution: In the antepartum management of a pregnant woman with type 1 diabetes, glycemic control is the most important factor to monitor. Tight glycemic control helps reduce the risk of complications for both the mother and the fetus.

questions.text: A patient presents with digoxin toxicity. Pulse rate is 54/min with ECG evidence of 3rd degree heart block. What is the best treatment?
questions.solution:
Digitalis is a drug with a very narrow therapeutic index. Digitalis toxicity produces a variety of side effects including headache, nausea, vomiting, altered colour perception, halo vision and malaise. Serious adverse events include arrhythmias, mostly bradyarrhythmias due to the enhanced vagal tone. Tachyarrhythmia can also occur. Phenytoin is used to control atrial tachy arrhythmias and lignocaine for ventricular tachy arrhythmias.

Brady arrhythmias respond to withdrawal of digoxin, atropine or temporary pacing.

Digoxin-specific antibody fragments for hemodynamically compromising dysrhythmias, Mobitz II or third degree atrioventricular block, hyperkalemia (>5.5 meq/L; in acute poisoning only). Temporizing measures include atropine, dopamine, epinephrine, and external cardiac pacing for bradydysrhythmias and magnesium, lidocaine, or phenytoin, for ventricular tachydysrhythmias. Internal cardiac pacing and cardioversion can increase ventricular irritability and should be reserved for refractory cases

questions.text: The sequential onset of rigor mortis in various groups of muscles is given by which eponymous law/rule?
questions.solution:
Nysten's rule describes the sequential onset of rigor mortis in the various muscle groups.

Rigor mortis (cadaveric rigidity or death stiffening) refers to the stiffening and shortening of muscles following death. The basic sequence of the rigor mortis begins from the head and continues downwards the body. It disappears in the same order of appearance.

Heart (left chamber of the heart is affected first) is the first organ to undergo rigor mortis.

Externally, the muscles are affected in following order:

  1. Eyelids
  2. Neck & lower jaw
  3. Face
  4. Chest
  5. Upper limbs
  6. Abdomen
  7. Lower limbs
  8. Fingers & toes

Casper dictum is used in the estimation of time since death.

  • It states that a body decomposes in air twice as rapidly as in water (immersed body), and eight times as rapidly as in earth (buried body), if the environmental factors are the same.
  • Air : Water : Earth → 1 : 2 : 8

Curren's rule and McNaughten's rule deal with criminal responsibilities of an insane person.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology by KS Narayan Reddy, 35th Edition, Page Number-118.

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman at 36 weeks of gestation presents with decreased fetal movements. On examination, the fetal heart rate is normal, and ultrasound shows oligohydramnios. What is the most likely cause of oligohydramnios in this scenario?
questions.solution: Oligohydramnios in the setting of decreased fetal movements at 36 weeks of gestation is most likely due to fetal renal abnormalities, leading to reduced urine production. Fetal renal abnormalities can result in inadequate amniotic fluid volume.

questions.text: Action of the superior rectus muscle:
questions.solution:
The superior rectus muscle is one of the extraocular muscles responsible for controlling the movement of the eye. Its primary actions are elevation (looking upward), adduction (moving the eye medially toward the nose), and intorsion (rotating the top of the eyeball toward the nose). Therefore, the correct combination of actions for the superior rectus muscle are elevation, adduction, and intorsion, which corresponds to option (a).




Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia: Human Anatomy, Volume-3, 8th Edition, Page Number-235.

questions.text: All the following are causes of chronic constipation in children except_.
questions.solution:
Jejunal polyps are not typically associated with chronic constipation in children. Other conditions such as Hirschsprung disease, hypothyroidism, and strictures may contribute to chronic constipation.

Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 20th Edition, Page Number-1765.

questions.text: A 25-year-old pregnant woman at 38 weeks of gestation presents with regular uterine contractions and ruptured membranes. On examination, the cervix is 5 cm dilated, and the vertex is engaged. Fetal heart rate monitoring shows persistent variable decelerations. What is the most likely cause of variable decelerations in this situation?
questions.solution: Variable decelerations in fetal heart rate monitoring are most commonly associated with cord compression. In this scenario, the rupture of membranes and engagement of the vertex can lead to cord compression during uterine contractions. Amnioinfusion is done when variable accelerations are seen.

questions.text: A 47-year-old male presented with chronic diarrhea, abdominal pain, and weight loss. On esophagogastroduodenoscopy, it showed increased mucosal folds-multiple peptic ulcers. Which hormone increase will be noted in this condition?
questions.solution:
In Hypergastrinemia or Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, there is an increased level of gastrin. Gastrinoma, a neuroendocrine tumor, produces excess gastrin. This condition leads to severe and chronic hypergastrinemia, resulting in peptic ulcer disease, often refractory and severe, known as Zollinger-Ellison syndrome. Clinical manifestations include abdominal pain, diarrhea, and gastroesophageal reflux.

Reference: Textbook of Practical Physiology by GK Pal, 2nd Edition, Page Number-336.

questions.text: Test for diagnosis of HSV encephalitis
questions.solution:
The primary diagnostic test for HSV encephalitis is CSF PCR. It is 96 % sensitive and 99% specific. It has got a fairly high negative predictive value, if the pre test probability of HSV is low. It is not affected by antiviral treatment for up to 7 days. Only 20% CSF samples will be; positive after 2 weeks of illness.

The CSF antibody testing also aids in diagnosis of herpes simplex virus encephalitis. But the detection of antigens and antibodies typically occurs after one week of the infection, which makes acute diagnosis impossible with antibodies. Useful in patients With more than one week of infection, and in whom CSF PCR is negative.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman at 34 weeks of gestation is diagnosed with severe preeclampsia. What is the mainstay of management to prevent eclampsia in this patient?
questions.solution: The mainstay of management to prevent eclampsia in a pregnant woman with severe preeclampsia is the administration of magnesium sulfate. Magnesium sulfate has been shown to reduce the risk of eclampsia in women with severe preeclampsia.

questions.text: A patient presented with multiple erythematous scaly lesion on the body. He also complained of painful swollen fingers were noted along with an the inflamed wrist joint. What is the Treatment of choice ?
questions.solution:

  • Koebner's/Isomorphic phenomenon (lesions at site of trauma)
  • Painful inflamed joints suggest a diagnosis of Psoriatic arthritis
  • Treatment of choice - methotrexate

questions.text: Hoarseness of voice after surgery. Which does not lead to this condition during surgery?
questions.solution:
• Hoarseness of Voice is a complication of RLN injury.
  • Recurrent laryngeal nerve is a branch of Vagus nerve, hooks around the Arch of aorta on left and around Right SCA on the right and ascends up and runs very close to Inferior thyroid artery.
  • The nerve runs posterior to thyroid and enters larynx at cricothyroid joint. This entry point is at the level of BERRY LIGAMENT, the point of maximum risk of injury is here.
  • Nerve can be located in BEAHR'S Triangle- Bounded by Tracheoesophageal groove, Inferior Thyroid Artery and Carotid artery.
  • The nerve can be found on mobilizing the thyroid gland on the most postero lateral portion of gland called as Tubercle of Zuckerkandl.

Reference: Bailey and Love 28th Edition page 852

questions.text: A 65-year-old male, diabetic and hypertensive patient, taking several drugs presented with septicemia. Serum creatinine levels are 6.7 mg/dL with creatinine clearance <50 ml/min. Which of the following drugs should be stopped promptly?
questions.solution:
Metformin should be avoided in patients with renal impairment as it carries the risk of lactic acidosis. It is contraindicated in conditions such as renal disease, liver disease, heart failure, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and in elderly patients.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page Number-299

questions.text: In microbiology, two types of organisms are there: acid-fast organisms and non-acid-fast organisms. The third category is the partial acid-fast organisms. Which among the following is a partial acid-fast organism?
questions.solution:
Partial acid-fast organisms show less affinity for the primary stain, and less concentration of sulfuric acid is used for decolorization. Examples of partial acid-fast bacteria include Mycobacterium leprae and Nocardia.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Page Number-13.

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman at 20 weeks of gestation presents with vaginal bleeding. On ultrasound, the placenta is visualized extending to the margin of the internal cervical os. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: The scenario of placenta extending to the margin of the internal cervical os at 20 weeks of gestation is indicative of placenta previa. Placenta previa is a condition where the placenta partially or completely covers the internal cervical os. The main sign of placenta previa is bright red vaginal bleeding, usually without pain, after 20 weeks of pregnancy.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male with sickle cell anemia presents to the emergency department with severe pain in his left leg. Physical examination reveals an edematous and tender left lower extremity. Radiographs show no evidence of fracture. Laboratory studies reveal a hemoglobin level of 7.8 g/dL, a white blood cell count of 15,000 cells/mm3, and a platelet count of 400,000/mm3. What is the most likely cause of the patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Patients with sickle cell anemia are prone to vaso-occlusive crises, where sickled red blood cells obstruct small blood vessels, causing severe pain. The clinical presentation, along with the laboratory findings, is consistent with a sickle cell crisis.

Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th Edition, Page Number-446

questions.text: A patient presents with sudden onset aphasia and right hemiparesis. On examination BP is 160 /110 mm Hg. CT Scan of the patient is normal. What is the next best step in management ?
questions.solution: The next best step is to find out the source of thrombus and treat if there is a large vessel occlusion. CT angiography of vessels in the head and neck is done to find the source of the clot.

questions.text: In disaster management, the following options are true except:
questions.solution:
Explanation for why option C is the answer

Mass vaccination: While mass vaccination campaigns can be an important public health intervention, they are not always a standard component of disaster management. The need for mass vaccination would depend on factors such as the type of disaster, the presence of infectious disease outbreaks, and the vulnerability of the affected population. Therefore, while mass vaccination may be relevant in certain disaster situations, it is not universally applicable to all disaster scenarios.

A. Triage: Triage is a crucial aspect of disaster management that involves rapidly assessing and prioritizing the medical treatment of individuals based on the severity of their injuries or medical conditions. It helps medical personnel allocate limited resources efficiently to save as many lives as possible. Therefore, triage is an essential component of disaster response.

B. Rehabilitation: Rehabilitation is the phase of disaster management that focuses on restoring and rebuilding communities and infrastructure affected by a disaster. It includes activities such as reconstruction, providing support services to affected individuals, and facilitating their recovery and return to normal life. Rehabilitation efforts aim to enhance the resilience of communities and promote long-term recovery.

D. Disaster response: Disaster response encompasses a broad range of activities undertaken immediately after a disaster to address the needs of affected populations and mitigate further harm. It includes search and rescue operations, medical assistance, shelter provision, distribution of relief supplies, and other essential interventions aimed at saving lives and alleviating suffering.

questions.text: As per the NMC rules, if any request is made for medical records, the documents shall be issued within the period of:
questions.solution:
As per the National Medical Commission (Professional conduct, etiquette, and ethics/regulations, 2002 amendment)-

  • Indoor patients records should be kept for - 3 years.
  • A doctor should provide the medical records within 5 days when the patient or his/her authorized representative makes a request for it.

As per Director General of Health Services (DGHS), Ministry of health and F.W., Govt. of India,

  • Medical Records of indoor patients are stored in digitized form - indefinitely.
  • Medical Records in hard copy should be stored as follows:
    1. OPD records - 3 years.
    2. In-patient's medical records - 3 years.
    3. Medico-legal registers and case sheets - 10 years or till the disposal of ongoing cases in any of the courts related to these records.

Reference: Online Resource MC website Chapter 7 https://www.mciindia.org/CMS/rules-regulations/code-of-medical-ethics-regulations-2002

questions.text: A 35-year-old pregnant woman at 39 weeks of gestation presents with severe abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. On examination, the uterus is tender, and fetal heart rate monitoring shows late decelerations. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: The clinical presentation of severe abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, uterine tenderness, and late decelerations in fetal heart rate monitoring is suggestive of placental abruption. Placental abruption is a medical emergency that requires prompt intervention. The most appropriate management is emergency delivery of the fetus and address the potential for ongoing haemorrhage.

questions.text: A patient can recognize a person by name but not by face. The lesion is likely to be present in which lobe?

questions.text: Elements of primary health care include all the following except:
questions.solution:
Why the other options are not correct:

A. Adequate supply of safe water and basic sanitation: Access to clean water and proper sanitation is essential for preventing waterborne diseases and promoting public health. It is a fundamental component of primary health care as it addresses the basic environmental determinants of health.

B. Providing essential drugs: Ensuring access to essential drugs is a crucial aspect of primary health care. It involves making essential medications available and affordable to all individuals, especially in resource-limited settings. This helps in managing common health conditions and preventing complications.

D. Health education: Health education plays a vital role in primary health care by empowering individuals and communities to make informed decisions about their health. It involves raising awareness about preventive measures, healthy lifestyles, and the importance of seeking timely medical care. Health education promotes health literacy and encourages active participation in maintaining well-being.

In contrast, a sound referral system, while important for comprehensive health care delivery, is not typically considered an element of primary health care. Referral systems facilitate the transfer of patients between different levels of care, such as from primary care facilities to secondary or tertiary care facilities, when specialized services are needed. While referrals may occur within the context of primary health care, the establishment of a sound referral system extends beyond the scope of primary health care and involves coordination between various levels of the healthcare system.

questions.text: A 78 year old female was brought to emergency room for acute exacerbation of Asthma, for which Salbutamol was given, however no improvement was noticed. Her physician has decided to add Intravenous Corticosteroids and Theophylline, her condition improved dramatically. By which of the following mechanism Corticosteroids would have improved the condition?
questions.solution:
Corticosteroids improved the condition by increasing the responsiveness to salbutamol.

Mechanism of action of Corticosteroids in acute asthma attack:

Increases responsiveness to Beta-2 Agonists

Decreases Mucous Secretion

Decreases Inflammatory cell response.

Steroids increase the transcription of beta 2 receptor genes and hence increases responsiveness to beta-2 agonists.

Theophylline increase effects of steroids by activating enzyme Histone Deacetylase which is the target for steroids as well.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, Page no. 249

questions.text: A 27-year-old pregnant woman at 34 weeks of gestation is diagnosed with gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM). What is the primary goal of management in this patient?
questions.solution: The primary goal of management in a pregnant woman with gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) is achieving normal blood glucose levels. Tight glycemic control is essential to reduce the risk of complications for both the mother and the fetus.

questions.text: Which of the following macrophages plays a role in the pitting of RBCs to form Heinz bodies and Howell-Jolly bodies?
questions.solution:
Splenic macrophages are responsible for "pitting" of red cells, the process by which inclusions such as Heinz bodies and Howell-Jolly bodies are excised. They also remove particles such as bacteria from the blood.

On examination, the blood pressure is elevated, and laboratory tests show elevated liver enzymes. What is the most likely diagnosis, and what is the recommended next step in management?
questions.solution: The clinical presentation of severe right-sided abdominal pain, elevated blood pressure, and elevated liver enzymes is consistent with acute fatty liver of pregnancy. Delivery is the recommended next step in management to resolve the condition and prevent complications.

questions.text: Which anti TB drug causes visual disturbances?
questions.solution:
c. Ethambutol:

  • Ethambutol is well known for its potential to cause optic neuritis, which can lead to irreversible visual disturbances, including blurred vision, decreased visual acuity, and changes in colour vision. This side effect is dose-dependent and occurs more commonly with higher doses or prolonged use of the drug. Regular monitoring of visual acuity and color vision is recommended during treatment with Ethambutol to detect any signs of optic neuritis early.

Explanation to why other options are not correct:

a. INH (Isoniazid):

  • INH is primarily associated with hepatotoxicity (liver damage) and peripheral neuropathy as its major adverse effects. It does not typically cause visual disturbances.

b. Rifampicin:

  • Rifampicin is known to cause various side effects, such as hepatotoxicity, gastrointestinal disturbances, and flu-like symptoms. However, it is not typically associated with visual disturbances.

d. Streptomycin:

  • Streptomycin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic used in the treatment of TB. Its common side effects include ototoxicity (damage to the inner ear leading to hearing loss) and nephrotoxicity (kidney damage). It is not typically associated with visual disturbances.

In summary, while all anti-TB drugs have potential side effects, Ethambutol is specifically associated with causing visual disturbances, particularly optic neuritis. Therefore, option c is the correct choice.

choices.text: Initiate iron chelation therapy with deferasirox
Increase the frequency of blood transfusions

questions.text: A 25-year-old female with beta-thalassemia major presents to the clinic with weakness and fatigue. Her hemoglobin level is 7.5 g/dL. She has received multiple blood transfusions in the past. Her ferritin level is 1500 ng/mL. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
In beta-thalassemia major, frequent blood transfusions are needed to maintain hemoglobin levels. However, repeated transfusions can lead to iron overload, as indicated by the elevated ferritin level. The most appropriate next step is to initiate iron chelation therapy with deferasirox to prevent organ damage caused by excess iron.

Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th Edition, Page Number 439-447.

questions.text: In testicular feminization syndrome, gonadectomy is indicated:
questions.solution:
Patients of Testicular Feminization syndrome (Androgen insensitivity) are genotypically males (Karyotype 46XY) but phenotypically females (i.e. male pseudo hermaphroditism).

Due to the presence of Y chromosome, gonads are testis which remain intra-abdominal and have a malignant potential (Most common = Gonadoblastoma, Dysgerminoma).

Therefore, testis should be removed in such patients. B/L Laparoscopic Gonadectomy is the preferred procedure.

As far as timing of Gonadectomy is concerned

In a patient with complete androgen insensitivity, the testis should be removed after pubertal development is complete to prevent malignant degeneration.

Whereas, in cases other than Testicular Feminization syndrome, if patient has XY Karyotype and she develops virilization, the testes should be removed immediately to preserve the female phenotype and to promote female gender identity.

questions.text: Mosquito whose larvae lies horizontal on the water and rests parallel to the surface of the water is:
questions.solution:
A. Aedes: Aedes mosquitoes typically have larvae that do not lie horizontally on the surface of the water. Instead, Aedes larvae usually position themselves at an angle or hang downwards from the water's surface.

C. Culex: As previously explained, Culex larvae do not lie horizontally on the water's surface either. They typically hang at an angle with their bodies partially submerged, but they do not rest parallel to the surface.

D. Mansonia: Mansonia mosquitoes also do not have larvae that lie horizontally on the water's surface. Their larvae typically hang downwards from the surface or attach themselves to vegetation or other objects near the water.

So, Anopheles mosquitoes are unique among the options listed because their larvae do indeed lie horizontally on the surface of the water, resting parallel to the surface. This positioning is characteristic of Anopheles larvae and is important for their respiration, feeding, and development. Anopheles larvae possess specialized structures that allow them to anchor themselves to the water's surface tension while they feed on microorganisms and other organic matter.

In summary, option B is the correct answer because Anopheles mosquitoes are known for having larvae that rest parallel to the surface of the water. The other options are not correct because their larvae do not exhibit this behaviour.

questions.text: A 56 year old male patient with history of ongoing cancer chemotherapy came to medicine department and diagnosed of having thrombo-embolism. Which of the following is the anticoagulant of choice for the management of cancer associated thrombo-embolism?
questions.solution:
Low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH) is the preferred agent because of more bioavailability, lack of need for anticoagulant monitoring, and long t1/2

Heparin, LMWH, or fondaparinux can be used to initiate treatment of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism. They also can be used for the initial management of patients with unstable angina or acute myocardial infarction

For most of these indications, LMWH or fondaparinux has replaced continuous heparin infusions because of their pharmacokinetic advantages as below:

The more important advantages of LMW heparins are pharmacokinetic:

  • Better subcutaneous bioavailability (70–90%) compared to UFH (20–30%): Variability in response is minimized.
  • Longer and more consistent monoexponential t½ (4–6 hours); making possible once daily s.c. administration.
  • Since aPTT/clotting times are not prolonged, laboratory monitoring is not needed; dose is calculated on body weight basis.

LMWH or fondaparinux can be used for out-of-hospital management of patients with deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics 13th edition, Page no. 589

questions.text: A newborn baby is having cyanotic spell at birth with difficulty in breathing. The symptoms improve with crying. what is urgent priority in the management of the given condition?
questions.solution:
The above features suggestive of

Bilateral complete choanal atresia

  • It is a neonatal airway emergency, because neonates are obligatory nasal breathers. (Mouth breathing is an acquired reflex)
  • Baby is cyanosed immediately after birth but turns pink on crying (blue baby turns pink on crying
  • Immediate management is putting wide bore nipple in baby's mouth to keep it open
  • It is called McGovern's Technique.
  • Then do tracheostomy.
  • At one year of age, plan to do recanalization surgery

Gestational age of the current pregnancy

questions.text: A female has a history of previous cesarean delivery. She is interested in attempting a trial of labor after cesarean (TOLAC). What factor is most important in determining the eligibility for TOLAC?
questions.solution: The type of uterine incision from the previous cesarean delivery is the most important factor in determining the eligibility for a trial of labor after cesarean (TOLAC). A low transverse uterine incision is associated with a lower risk of uterine rupture during TOLAC.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male chronic liver disease presented to the emergency department with features of decompensation. Which component is not a part of the MELD score for predicting survival ?
questions.solution: The Model for End-Stage Liver Disease (MELD) score includes three components: serum creatinine, serum bilirubin, and the international normalized ratio (INR). Albumin is not a part of the MELD score.

choices.text: The vertigo sensation persists for 2 - 3 hours
Otoconia most commonly migrate to posterior semicircular canal to cause this entity
There is no hearing loss in this condition
BPPV is the most common cause of peripheral vertigo

questions.text: All are true about benign paroxysmal positional vertigo except
questions.solution:
BPPV is the most common cause of peripheral vertigo. This disease is more common in females.

Cause - otoconia gets displaced and reaches the semicircular canal (the most commonly involved canal is posterior semicircular canal).

Chief complaint- vertigo for few seconds on changing head position. Vertigo is with nausea and vomiting. There is no hearing loss in this condition.

Diagnostic test of BPPV- Dix Hallpike's manoeuvre.

Treatment of BPPV- Epleys maneuver (particle repositioning maneuver)- it is the treatment of choice

If a patient of BPPV does not respond to this treatment for months, then the patient gets chronic BPPV, this leads to recurrent disabling vertigo. Then this patient is a candidate for surgery called singular neurectomy (singular nerve supplies posterior SCC).

questions.text: Which among the following diseases is referred to as jeep disease?
questions.solution:
Pilonidal sinus

  • The term pilonidal sinus describes a condition found in the natal cleft overlying the coccyx, consisting of one or more, usually non-infected, midline openings, which communicate with a fibrous track lined by granulation tissue and containing hair lying loosely within the lumen.
  • A common affliction amongst the military, it has been referred to as 'jeep disease'.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery, chapter 80, Edition 28th, Pg: 1423

questions.text: A 25-year old patient named Ram has a history of chronic asthma, and is on treatment with theophylline. He developed an upper respiratory tract infection. Which of the following is the most suitable option to treat his upper respiratory tract infection?
questions.solution:
Theophylline metabolism can be affected by certain drugs. Azithromycin does not affect the hepatic CYP3A4 enzymes significantly. Interaction with drugs like theophylline, carbamazepine, warfarin, terfenadine, and cisapride is not likely.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page Number-246,805.

questions.text: An 8-year-old patient presents with fever, sore throat, and lymphadenopathy. On examination, mild hepatosplenomegaly is found. Peripheral blood film shows 20% atypical lymphocytosis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Infectious mononucleosis, caused by Epstein-Barr virus, presents with fever, sore throat, atypical lymphocytosis, and hepatosplenomegaly. It's often spread through contact with infected saliva from the mouth. Symptoms can take between 4 to 6 weeks to appear and usually do not last beyond 4 months.

questions.text: A 67-year-old male presents with dyspnea and a mass in the lung. The clinician wanted to make a confirmatory diagnosis. Electron microscopy was seen, what is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Long and thin microvilli are characteristic of mesothelioma.

questions.text: A 37 year-old woman brought to pulmonologist with a recent history of having viral sore throat followed by severe coughing and chest tightness after exercise. Which of the following agent is best suitable for this woman as a part of management?
questions.solution:
Inhaled salbutamol delivered mostly from pressurized metered dose inhaler (pMDI) produces bronchodilatation within 5 min and the action lasts for 2-4 hours.

It is, therefore, used to abort and terminate attacks of asthma, but is not suitable for round-the-clock prophylaxis.

Muscle tremors are the dose related side effect. Palpitation, restlessness,nervousness, throat irritation and ankle edema can also occur. Hypokalaemia is a possible complication.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, Page no. 242

questions.text: A second-year student went to the surgery posting for the first time where he saw a patient who had complained of severe abdominal pain and diarrhea for 4 days. Stool was watery for the first 24 hrs, then blood was coming in it. In one of the colonoscopy findings, it was written as Hemorrhagic colitis. Hemorrhagic colitis is caused by which strain of E coli?
questions.solution:
Enterohemorrhagic E. coli causes hemorrhagic colitis or Hemolytic uremic syndrome. It is associated with severe bloody diarrhea.

Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) is a thrombotic microangiopathy (TMA) characterized by thrombocytopenia, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, and acute kidney injury.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Page Number-1028.

questions.text: In assessing the validity of a screening test, those subjects who test positive with the screening test but test negative by the gold standard test are called:
questions.solution:
In assessing the validity of a screening test, it's crucial to understand the terminology used to categorize the results. These terms are based on comparing the screening test results with those of a gold standard test, which is considered the most accurate diagnostic tool available.

c. FP (False Positive): These are cases where the screening test incorrectly identifies individuals as positive for the condition, but the gold standard test reveals that they do not actually have the disease or condition. This is often referred to as a "false alarm" or a Type I error. This is an important consideration in assessing the validity of a screening test because false positives can lead to unnecessary follow-up tests, treatments, and anxiety for patients.

Therefore, in the context of assessing the validity of a screening test, individuals who test positive with the screening test but test negative by the gold standard test are referred to as false positives (FP).

Why other options are not correct

a. TP (True Positive): These are cases where the screening test correctly identifies individuals as positive for the condition, and the gold standard test confirms the presence of the disease or condition.

b. TN (True Negative): These are cases where the screening test correctly identifies individuals as negative for the condition, and the gold standard test confirms the absence of the disease or condition.

d. FN (False Negative): These are cases where the screening test incorrectly identifies individuals as negative for the condition, but the gold standard test shows that they actually have the disease or condition. This is known as a "missed diagnosis" or a Type II error.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman consults a dermatologist to evaluate and treat her glabellar lines (frown lines on the forehead just above the nose). After her treatment options are explained, the patient asks the dermatologist to administer Botox (botulinum type A). Botox injections smooth out the glabellar lines by which of the following methods?
questions.solution:
Botulinum toxin (Botox) induces muscle relaxation by blocking the release of acetylcholine from the nerve terminals, leading to flaccid paralysis. In cosmetic use, Botox injections are employed to reduce the appearance of facial wrinkles.

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 25th Edition, Page Number-125.

questions.text: Endoscopic third ventriculostomy can be used in treatment of which type of hydrocephalus?
questions.solution:
Endoscopic Third Ventriculostomy (ETV) -

This procedure is useful in obstructive (non-communicating) hydrocephalus due to aqueduct stenosis.

A neuroendoscope is inserted into the frontal horn of the lateral ventricle and then into the third ventricle via the foramen of Monro.

The floor of the ventricle is then opened between the mammillary bodies and the pituitary recess.

Free drainage between the third ventricle and the adjacent subarachnoid cisterns is then possible, without the infection risk posed by implanted tubing.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 48, Cranial neurosurgery, Pg: 706.

questions.text: A 78-year-old diabetic patient named Rajubhai, being treated with an oral hypoglycemic agent by some quack practitioner develops generalized weakness, nausea & vomiting. His serum sodium levels are 125 mEq/l. Which one of the following agents should be stopped immediately and replaced by a safer agent?
questions.solution:
Chlorpropamide is a long-acting sulfonylurea oral hypoglycemic. It is known to reduce urine volume in diabetes insipidus of pituitary origin but not in renal diabetes insipidus. It sensitizes the kidney to antidiuretic hormone (ADH) action.

Chlorpropamide is associated with an increased risk of hypoglycemia, especially in elderly patients, and it can lead to a syndrome known as SIADH (syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion), causing hyponatremia. In the presented case, where the patient has generalized weakness, nausea, vomiting, and hyponatremia, discontinuing chlorpropamide is warranted.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page Number-644.

questions.text: Mosquitoes that breed in dirty water collection are-
questions.solution:
Explanation of why option B is true and why the other options are not:

A. Anopheles: Anopheles mosquitoes typically breed in clean, clear water sources such as freshwater lakes, ponds, and slow-moving streams. They prefer clean water bodies for the development of their larvae. Anopheles mosquitoes are vectors of malaria, and they often breed in natural water collections like puddles, marshes, and rice fields.

C. Aedes: Aedes mosquitoes, including species like Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus, are known for breeding in small, artificial containers filled with clean or stagnant water. These containers can include discarded tires, flower pots, and water storage containers around human habitats. Aedes mosquitoes are vectors of diseases such as dengue fever, Zika virus, and chikungunya. They typically prefer clean or stagnant water rather than dirty water.

D. Mansonia: Mansonia mosquitoes breed in freshwater habitats such as marshes, swamps, and areas with abundant vegetation. They lay their eggs on the surface of the water, often attaching them to floating vegetation. Mansonia larvae are found in relatively clean water bodies and are not typically associated with breeding in dirty water collections.

Culex mosquitoes, on the other hand, are known to breed in various water sources, including polluted or dirty water collections. They are commonly found in urban environments where there are containers or pools of standing water contaminated with organic matter, such as sewage, decaying vegetation, or animal waste. Culex mosquitoes are vectors of diseases such as West Nile virus and filariasis. Their ability to breed in polluted water collections makes them a significant nuisance and health concern in urban and suburban areas.

In summary, option B is the correct answer because Culex mosquitoes are known for breeding in dirty water collections. The other options are not correct because they are associated with breeding in different types of water sources.

questions.text: A patient was given halothane for general anesthesia. He developed rigidity and hyperthermia. These symptoms are most likely due to which of the following ions?
questions.solution:
Halothane can cause a syndrome known as malignant hyperthermia, characterized by hyperthermia and skeletal muscle rigidity. This is often associated with an abnormal release of calcium ions from the sarcoplasmic reticulum in the muscle cells.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th Edition, Page Number-413.

questions.text: Diagnostic power of a test to correctly exclude a disease is given by:
questions.solution:
The diagnostic power of a test to correctly exclude a disease is indicated by its Negative Predictive Value (NPV). NPV measures the probability that individuals who test negative on the diagnostic test truly do not have the disease. A high NPV indicates that the test is effective in ruling out the disease in those who test negative, providing reassurance that they are truly disease-free.

d. NPV (Negative Predictive Value): NPV measures the proportion of true negative results among all negative results. It indicates the likelihood that a negative test result truly indicates the absence of the disease. NPV is directly related to the ability of a test to correctly exclude a disease.

Why other options are not correct

a. Sensitivity: Sensitivity measures the ability of a test to correctly identify individuals who have the disease or condition (true positives) among all individuals who actually have the disease. It indicates the proportion of true positive results among all individuals who actually have the disease. Sensitivity is not about excluding a disease but rather detecting it.

b. Specificity: Specificity measures the ability of a test to correctly identify individuals who do not have the disease or condition (true negatives) among all individuals who do not have the disease. While specificity is important for ruling in a disease, it doesn't directly reflect the ability to exclude a disease.

c. PPV (Positive Predictive Value): PPV measures the proportion of true positive results among all positive results. It indicates the likelihood that a positive test result truly indicates the presence of the disease. PPV is associated with the ability to confirm the presence of a disease, not to exclude it. PPV measures the probability that individuals with a positive test result actually have the disease. It depends on both sensitivity and specificity but is not specifically about excluding the disease.

questions.text: Which anastomosis is performed in bilroth-II surgery?
questions.solution:
Billroth II gastrectomy

  • In Billroth II gastrectomy, or its close relation Pólya gastrectomy, the antrum and distal body of the stomach are mobilised by opening the greater and lesser omentum and dividing the gastroepiploic arteries, right gastric artery and the left gastric artery arcade at the limit of the resection.
  • The duodenum is closed off either by suture or using staples, sometimes with difficulty in patients with a very deformed duodenum.
  • Following resection, the distal end of the stomach is narrowed by the closure of the lesser curve aspect of the remnant.
  • The greater curve aspect is then anastomosed, usually in a retrocolic fashion, to the jejunum, leaving as short an afferent loop as feasible.
  • A common cause of morbidity in this procedure is leakage from the duodenal stump, which is particularly associated with kinking of the afferent loop.
  • Leakage from the gastrojejunal anastomosis is unusual unless it is under tension or the stomach has been devascularised during the mobilisation.
  • Recurrence of the ulcer at the stoma is uncommon but can occur, especially as this procedure is traditionally not combined with the vagotomy.
  • In the majority of expert centres, a Roux-en-Y reconstruction rather than the Billroth II procedure is performed because postoperative function is better.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery, chapter: 67, Edition: 28th, Pg: 1160

questions.text: Which of the following is the classic renal tumor associated with tuberous sclerosis?
questions.solution:
The classic renal tumor associated with tuberous sclerosis is angiomyolipoma. However, RCCs may be sometimes seen in intimate connection with angiomyolipomas.


Reference: Rosai and Ackerman's Surgical Pathology, 11th Edition, Page Number-1026.

choices.text: It is the ratio of energy from protein to total energy in diet
It is the ratio of total nitrogen retained by total nitrogen intake multiplied by 100
It is the amount of one amino acid per gram of a protein divided by the amount of same amino acid per gram of egg protein
If the NPU is high the amount of protein requirement in diet is high

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about Net Protein Utilization?
questions.solution:
b. It is the ratio of total nitrogen retained by total nitrogen intake multiplied by 100: This statement accurately describes Net Protein Utilization (NPU). NPU is calculated by dividing the total nitrogen retained by the total nitrogen intake and then multiplying by 100 to express it as a percentage. NPU reflects the proportion of dietary protein that is retained and utilized by the body for various physiological functions.

Why the other option is not correct:

a. It is the ratio of energy from protein to total energy in the diet: This statement describes Protein Efficiency Ratio (PER) or Protein Energy Ratio (PER), not Net Protein Utilization (NPU). PER or PER is the ratio of weight gain to protein intake and is related to the efficiency of protein utilization for growth or maintenance, whereas NPU specifically focuses on nitrogen balance.

c. It is the amount of one amino acid per gram of a protein divided by the amount of the same amino acid per gram of egg protein: This statement describes Protein Digestibility Corrected Amino Acid Score (PDCAAS), not NPU. PDCAAS is a method used to evaluate the quality of dietary protein by comparing the amino acid profile of a protein to that of a reference protein, typically egg protein.

d. If the NPU is high, the amount of protein requirement in the diet is high: This statement is incorrect. A high NPU indicates that a larger proportion of the protein consumed is being retained and utilized by the body, but it does not necessarily mean that the overall protein requirement in the diet needs to be higher. Protein requirements depend on various factors such as age, sex, weight, physical activity level, and physiological state (e.g., pregnancy, lactation), rather than solely on NPU.

In summary, option B accurately describes Net Protein Utilization (NPU), which is the ratio of total nitrogen retained by total nitrogen intake multiplied by 100. Options A, C, and D describe other concepts related to protein quality or efficiency but do not accurately represent NPU. Therefore, option B is the correct answer.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common bacterial cause of acute exacerbations of COPD?
questions.solution:
Haemophilus influenzae is the most common bacterial cause of acute exacerbations of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Moraxella catarrhalis is the second most common bacterial cause of acute exacerbation of COPD.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page Number-707.

questions.text: All of the following statements about Wilson's disease are true except?
questions.solution: Wilson's disease is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by defective hepatic copper transport, leading to copper accumulation throughout the body. Laboratory findings supporting the diagnosis include low levels of serum copper and serum ceruloplasmin, elevated hepatic transaminase levels, aminoaciduria, and hemolytic anemia. Increased urinary excretion of copper (>100 μg/24 h) is an important diagnostic test for Wilson's disease.

questions.text: All are seen in Henoch-Schoenlein Purpura, except__.
questions.solution:
Palpable purpura in HSP occurs in the absence of any platelet abnormalities.

Diagnostic criteria for HSP/IgA Vasculitis: Palpable purpura (on buttocks & lower limbs) plus any 2 of the following;

  1. Diffuse abdominal pain
  2. Tissue biopsy showing IgA deposits
  3. Arthritis or arthralgia
  4. Renal involvement in the form of glomerulonephritis

Reference: OP Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition, Box 22.4.

questions.text: A pregnant female was given indomethacin for treatment of pain. Which of the following can be the likely outcome in the baby?
questions.solution:
Premature closure of the ductus arteriosus is a rare phenomenon. It is thought to be caused by one of three things: abnormal levels of produced and circulating prostaglandin, maternal ingestion of prostaglandin synthase inhibitors or it can be idiopathic.

Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) have been associated with premature closure of the ductus arteriosus (DA). Ibuprofen is a member of the NSAID class with potential obstetric treatment advantages despite a 40-fold decreased potency compared to indomethacin.

Reference: William’s Obstetrics, 26th Edition, Page Number- 144.
